Very very interesting video! Although I would say that I lean to the right but there's no denying the progressives' creativity!    Just on a few points about criticism of capitalism though, I hear this being mentioned time and time again, I believe it to be factually wrong, please correct me if you guys have any thoughts.    1. Workers being stripped with any autonomy and the value of their work is basically just being handed to the 'lizards' that does nothing. I believe this is the image you are trying to paint, and I believe this to be inaccurate.    Any student of commerce would know profit comes with risks. The 'lizards' of the companies generally face a lot more risks and stress, most of them work longer hours, have less of a personal life because of their responsibility towards, if all else disregarded, their own interests and stake within the company. In most circumstances, employees are free of responsibility, stress and risks. Any employee who are severely mistreated, underpaid by their employer, could see his/her talent realised by a competing firm. This is generally the case. While there are certainly exceptions to the rule, it seems to me a mistake to paint all workers contributions flowing up to the 'lizards' and only able to maintain the bare minimum.    2. Market creating desires. Sure advertising does create some desires but nothing could be further from the entire truth in my view. In marketing there is a terminology called latent need. Which describes a need that the consumers might not have been aware but is catered for by a innovative product. A random example could be a smartphone. Before the smart phone, people might have been satisfied with going to the web via computer and call via a tedious phone book and a traditional phone. But the introduction of a smartphone made it easier and satisfied the latent needs of consumers. Once they realise how convenient the smartphone is they decide to consume the product. Whilst it is true this product is simply created, you could say, but does it not also satisfy the basic desire for things to be as convenient as possible? Surely it's just human nature to want to quality content such as contrapoint on a convenient smartphone without the need to carry a massive computer everywhere they go?    Anyway these are my thoughts. Just to clarify, there are many problems in our society and many of them stems from capitalism. However, some criticism of the systems that stemmed from Marxism are simply not correct in my opinion or at the very least very outdated.    Lastly, thank you for addressing the Communist Russia and China problem. As a Chinese, I assure you the those Communist regimes are not something you would like to experience.

I have been saying this for years, only to be accused by my Gay brethren of somehow--I dunno'--endorsing this white heteronormative macho racist bullcrap when I'm not.  I'm just trying to explain that there is a justified reason for their angst, which happens to be shared by everyone since Capitalism oppresses all people!  I used to think that technology would give humanity and society more leisure time and increased wages; but, it's not.  It's being used to unemployed we worker bees; and, if we cannot find a job, then the internal message is spread that we somehow must be lazy, despite there not being enough jobs since every recession permanently sheds jobs from the market as they are taken over by the still-employed to squeeze every scent paid to by that employee for their wage slavery.  Meanwhile, because the Oligarchs cannot see the long-term results of their actions, they financially squeeze the majority of us, while prices continue to rise, making it harder for use to buy much of anything.  Well, one would think it would sock these Oligarchs in the wallet, right?  No!  They have given up on making their money in the US and have set their sights on the asian countries and in Europe where people still have disposable income to spend!  And, our bought off politicians like, Nancy 'We're Capitalists' Pelosi does NOTHING to address these heinous problems.  They won't even let us have nice things like a Single Payer Healthcare System or Tuition-Free College for all that the Oligarchs have taken from us and by exploiting us!  Hell, Nancy just gave trump a blank check with no humanitarian strings attached to it, which means she's either a food, or just as evil as Trump!

I think you have misunderstood what capitalism is all about. Capitalism is not about having people work for other people, to leech of their means of production, like it seems to me that you are portraying capitalism. Capitalism is a system that favours the free market and trade. The whole idea of capitalism is that by leaving trade and the industry to private people with an interest to earn money people will get an insentive to produce better quality products and services to a better price because of their competition.   This of course applies to the labour market as well. You are only going to work for as much as your employer is willing to pay you and vice versa. This is why you have a choice to not sign an employement contract

You want, and use, all the benefits of capitalism and western civilization, and then crap on it from your penthouse view while failing to recognize or care about your own hypocrisy.   You are the very epitome of artificial virtue.  People like you, ironically enough, demonstrate exactly why socialism can't survive by your own very existence.  You would have literally NONE of what you have now, if you weren't living in a capitalist system, and despite your ostensible intellect and talent, you're apparently either oblivious to that fact, or are so fundamentally dishonest, you don't care about that fact, because you've successfully monetized other people's pain.  You CAPITALIZED on the ignorance of the evils of socialism.  It's a special kind of disgusting.   The equipment you use, the makeup you use, the real estate you use, the very foundation of EVERYTHING you do is only there because of a system which recognizes and leverages fundamentals of human nature to make the world go around. AKA- Capitalism.  With all its flaws, it's the only system which recognizes the value of the individual, and allows for lateral movement, and yet you seek to destroy it in favor of a system which invariably destroys everyone but the tiniest of fractions at the top. With the opening, I noticed that it seems to be the market's reaction to the  vast number of cultures  that have to be catered to (in order to maximize profit). That being the case: the most bland and inoffensive approach is the only way to ensure that no single culture is offended (and therefore, lose out on their revenue). Continuing that thought,  countries used to primarily be designed for a culture; to codify their collective set of values and protect them .  Some values are very specific to that country, while others have similar values that can translate over (IE: Western Europe) while others cannot (IE: the Middle-East) .When those values are debased through multiple cultural competition  they become lost. Because the values are now not shared, the perception of relatability  is no longer there. Now, the  less enviable traits  (greed, lust etc) are more likely to be expressed and manifest  increasingly over time. Free Trade (Capitalism) is only reflecting that loss, not the cause of it. When you addressed the rich,  I agree that it's not a very nice thing to spend one's money on ,essentially, useless items/services, but they are well within their right to do so. I believe that everyone  has 'negative  rights' (the right to not be robbed, murdered, raped or defrauded), but when it comes to 'positive rights' (universal healthcare, public education) there always is some form of extortion going on (I've heard it said as 'there's always a gun in the room'). You can definitely encourage people to act in a humanitarian way towards others who are not as well off (ostracization can be a powerful tool) , but when it escalates to the point of violence (whether outright or implied, such as with taxation), you're violating someone's right to their property.   Nevertheless, your presentation was entertaining.

Based on what you've described in the video, The problem doesn't seem to be capitalism itself but how we view the aspect of trade. People today expect to earn money from one person at the top of the chain instead of making small trades with other people to become the person at the top of the chain. Thusly these top dogs have security in their income and are able to spend money on advertisements to get their trade out to anyone that would buy it. If there were competitors that got more money without advertisements we would then see less advertisements. Think about it, when was the last time you responded to an ad and bought the thing(?), Most people will say practically never so why are there still ads on every platform? Either someone is directly giving them money or they see a competition.   It would make more sense that they have a competition to keep their advertisements going with the causation fallacy, e.g. 'We make ads and see customers, therefore the ads bring in customers.' Taking the ads out of the equation now, Why then do most people not make enough money to support themselves? 10:10 - 10:25 & 10:48 This is the perfect breakdown but not because of capitalism. Why are there so many people suffering homelessness and debt in the Federation (Talking about a continental nation shouldn't be on the same terms as talking about say Germany, more comparable to the entire EU by size and pop)? People are allowed to use their money as well or as poorly as they want but What causes homelessness and debt, a need for money. Why is there a need for money, i.e. Why are people going into Medical debt and student loan debt, and why at such a high rate? Lets pass the torch because we have to derive the answer, Why is Tuition and Medication so Costly in the US? _What are the requirements to sell education and Medication?_  Education; In order to sell/trade education you need a bachelor's in education with a major in a field you wish to educate but that is fine, in order to run an institution is just like any other business. Pay X money to your state and you will be permitted to stay running, and as individual teachers you also pay X money for your income working. Using Supply and Demand we know that the harder something is to produce then the higher it's price will be, e.g. Higher Tuition cost would be caused by higher tax rate. Larger campus = higher property tax. Medication; In order to sell/trade Medication whether it be a surgeon or a pharmacist requires a large amount of education with high grades to be accepted into a pay grade. You need a license to practice medicine in the US and that makes sense. However we have Welfare and state required insurance in some of the states, That is where medication is at the highest price and people are becoming indebted but there is more money to work with? We didn't change the Supply, The number of facilities that can practice medicine are the same but we yanked up Demand by giving people more money that the price of using equipment has skyrocketed and thusly leave people in debt for using the equipment.  Price is dictated by Supply and Demand, More comparative Demand makes things expensive so the goal of national economics (no matter the politics) is to lower Demand by comparison of Supply. If we make more Medical professionals/devises the price of medicine goes down, If we lower the establishing price for schools then we will have lower tuition. This is a reactionary scale so prices won't change within the hour, but by the next quarter the prices will go down significantly.   Write to your Governor or Congressman to lower taxes on schools and increase funding into medicine and we will have lower prices. If after effect the prices stay the same after a quarter you will know that is because someone/people got a *huge* raise and you shouldn't give them your business, they will either change or die out.

I think that You misunderstood the concept of rationalism under capitalism. What mises said in Human Action: 'Human action is necessarily always rational. The term 'rational
action' is therefore pleonastic and must be rejected as such. When
applied to the ultimate ends of action, the terms rational and irrational are inappropriate and meaningless. The ultimate end of
action is always the satisfaction of some desires of the acting man.
Since nobody is it1 a position to substitute his own value judgments
for those of the acting individual, it is vain to pass judgment on other people's aims and volitions. No man is qualified to declare what would
make another man happier or less discontented. The critic either tells
us what he believes he would aim at if he were in the place of his fellow; or, in dictatoria1 arrogance blithely disposing of his fellow's wilI
and aspirations, declarcs what condition of this other man would better
suit himself, the critic.
It is usual to call an action irrational if it aims, at the expense of
'material' and tangible advantages, at the attainment of 'ideal' or
'higher' satisfactions. In this sense people say, for instance-sometinles with approvaI, sometimes with disapproval-that a man who
sacrifices life, health, or wealth to the attainment of 'higher' goodslike fidelity to his religious, philosophical, and political convictions
or the freedom and flowering of his nation-is motivated by irrational
considerations. Howcvcr, the striving after these higher ends is neither
more nor less rational or irrational than that after other human ends.
It is a mistake to assume that the desire to procurc the bare necessities
of life and health is more rational, natural, or justified than the striving
after other goods or amenities. It is true that the appetite for food and
warmth is common to mcn and other mammals and that as a rule a
man who lacks food and shelter concentrates his efforts upon the
satisfaction of these urgcnt needs and does not care much for other
things. The impulse to live, to preserve one's own Iife, and to take
advantage of every opportunity of strengthening one's vital forces
is a primal feature of life, present in every living being. However, to

yield to this impulse is not-for man-an inevitable necessity.' Natalie, You lost me when you criticized Red Lobster and Chipotle. These chains are popular (and hence ubiquitous) because a lot of people judge them to provide a good value relative to the available alternatives. Many people feel they offer a good combination of tasty food, reasonable price, convenient location, pleasant ambiance,  good service, etc. Even if the fare on offer in the chain restaurants is not to your taste (for culinary, aesthetic or ideological reasons), there are lots of alternatives in a capitalist society. Heck, your can even produce and prepare your own meals or cooperating with like-minded people in a commune.    Meanwhile, people residing in the socialist societies your seem to favor, often have difficulty obtaining food that people in capitalist societies would view as substandard. And, notably, they are not free to criticize their governments/leaders for failing to provide adequate food, housing, security, etc.. There are lots of natural experiments in recent history and the present-day where people in neighboring socialist and capitalist countries (e.g., North Korea and South Korea, East Germany and West Germany, Venezuela and Chile) demonstrate the failure of socialist economies to provide for citizens' basic needs. You're right that there is still poverty in capitalist counties, but the lot of the poor in, say, America, is much better in absolute terms than the middle class in socialist countries or middle class Americans of a couple of generations ago.

The key difference between a company owner and an employee is the owner has money at risk in the company.   The owner had to pay a significant amount to become the owner, while the employee paid nothing to get the job.   If the company fails, the employee is out of a job, but they don't lose any wealth, just income.  The owner loses income and wealth, in most cases all their wealth.  That's why the owner has more privileges than the employee.  He or She has more at risk.

I think some times companies advertise to like, spread information that their product exists. It's true that a lot of the products that are shown in this video are luxuries and superfluous goods, like diamonds, sports cars, fancy booze and so on, and that most advertising for those things is going to be by definition manufacturing desire because no one really inherently desires those things. But people do inherently desire status, and that's not a product of capitalism, it's something our monkey brains like. I am supportive of changing norms around status and what it means to be successful and so on, especially as it discourages these mostly useless and often highly unethical products, but that doesn't seem like it needs to come from dismantling capitalism. Like lots of leftists have already come around to seeking uniqueness in status goods as opposed to costliness, and that happened under a capitalist regime. Isn't it reasonable to expect that it will continue to happen? There also do exists companies whose advertising practically serves more to inform consumers that a particular product or service exists rather than to manufacture desire for that product / push the high status of it. I realize that the angle ol' CP is pushing here is that the sheer extent of rhetorical techniques in most advertising ensures that no one is really rationally considering whether to buy a given product, but I just don't think it's universally true. I think the problem identified here is better explained by increased prosperity giving access to increasingly costly status goods without a good spiritual foundation to understand and enjoy them. I think saying that advertising, and by extension capitalism, is what caused this is reversing the cause and effect.

It isn't capitalism to issue 'loans' with money that doesn't exist and put the country into wage slavery. Socialist policies are to blame for so much of the things you are complaining about, like student loans,  high cost of living, and super inflated medical costs. I get there is a problem. I agree that poverty is out of control. I have a very, very different idea of how to fix it. The state is absolutely not needed to support true, free market capitalism. The state is required to support the imbalances created by the elite abusing the naivety of the public. Yes, if things continue as they are, the impoverished will rise up, they should! But I hope for the sake of society that when they do, they go after the people using government to prop them up, not people that actually earned their living. Being rich can and does happen from doing good things, because providing society with a useful product makes money, imagine that! What something's value is is ultimately subjective. Maybe spending $50 to get my nails done seems stupid to me, but that $50 is worth it to you because of the value you place on your appearance. Maybe the $50 I spend on a video game to drown my sorrows is a waste of money to you. In a free society, both of us can make those choices. In a socialist or worse, communist society, we don't get that much choice because someone decides for us what everything is worth, what products should be produced at all, who can have how much of them, and historically, it's done a shit job deciding how to even produce such basics as food, and people starve to death, in lot larger numbers than we are seeing today.   A concept that really seems to be misunderstood is what happens when rich people spend money on something you deem wasteful. So some guy spends a few million on a 'painting' of red with a little blue line on the side. Then the artist goes and spends that money on necessities and luxuries they want, and the money keeps moving forever, though the pocket of someone working minimum wage stocking groceries. Rich people and corporations are not the problem, the state protecting particular markets artificially inflating them is the problem. Bankers making money by loaning money that doesn't exist to people that can't even afford to pay mortgage and then taking their home away is the problem. The government spending money it doesn't have, making every child in this country born into debt for policies they didn't even get to vote on is the problem. The federal reserve taking income tax from the public that doesn't even cover the interest on the insane sums of money being wasted on wars, the drug war, the failing public education system, unrealistic green policies, those are the problem. By design, no matter what we do, we can NEVER pay back the federal reserve, because for every dollar printed, we owe that plus interest. It's a lose-lose scenario. Crypto is our hail mary, because it is currency outside of this corrupt monetary system.  Anyways, a lot of what you said is true, and I hope that the left and right can come together and fight the real monster here.

Capitalism isn't a political or economic system, it's a theory concerning free market transactions from an observational perspective. Everything is a subset of capitalism when you employ a capitalist perspective. Government is the tyrannical corporation that monopolized power, communism is just a different set of values of the underlying populace in favour of labour, etc.  The issue now becomes that to throw out consumer capitalism, you must look at the values of the mass people. The truth is neither the head of state, the richest CEOs, or any of us hold the power in capitalism because the market really does hold the power. Why can't Jeff Bezos hit 1 trillion USD? He doesn't actually hold *the* power, but yes he definitely holds a lot more than any of us do. Once you address how you'll make people see that these things aren't worth what they are currently willing to pay, then you haven't showed me that a revolution will be productive among the people, because capitalists follow markets and not the other way around.

I agree with the idea that spending millions of dollars on a painting is inefficient compared to what it could be used for. But I don't think anyone has a working utopian vision for the distribution of resources. In practice, it seems like the countries that have concerned themselves with this actually do less for their poor on absolute terms. The poor in capitalist countries may be massively dis-enfranchised relative to the rich and yet, the rise of capitalistic systems have resulted in the largest reduction in world poverty in the history of the world. If the current rate continues,  poverty (the kind that basically means you are starving to death in slow motion) will be eliminated in my life time. The worst problem of capitalism is that it does more to alleviate poverty and enhance equity and equality than any other system - but it doesn't *feel* like it. That is what ends up mattering in the end to most people. That the way I see it anyway.

Alot of the points brought up in this video as a critique seem to be more of a critique of government controlled programs rather than actual buisnesses. Capatalism is not forcing anybody to take up a job you dont like. It is the lack of competition brought in by a lack of a true free market that is making people buy overpriced shitty products or work for low wages. When capatalism is fully embraced, we actually have better services and cheaper products. Just look at privatised healthcare for instance. Privatised healthcare, although not very cheap, still has brought us innovations we would have never had if it werent for the competetive nature of the free market.  The free market I refer to is a market that provides the goods and services that the people want. The more people take part in this free market and the more trade that occurs, the more people will be more well off. This is the essence of capatalism and this is why I am proponent of it currently.  Now, I do not think that capatalism is perfect. On the contrary, I think capatalism will be a detriment to many people as we move into the future. Due to automation and technological advances, we are going to see more and more of workforce without jobs as their skill will no longer be applicable. Now, granted, this is still another 10 years away, but thats still pretty close in the grand scheme of things.

As someone that follows you to get the argument from the 'left side of the spectrum' I'm not really picking up your argument. Yes advertising is manufacturing desires but is it not the choice of the worker to actually spend their money? It's not like the working class is being forced to spend their money on worthless shit. The one topic I'd like critics of capitalism to address is spending habits. We have a 'keeping up with the joneses' mentality in this country which causes people to live outside of their means. More often than not people who are living paycheck to paycheck have a spending problem, not a wage problem. I'll concede that this materialism is reinforced by capitalist marketing but marketing will exist regardless of economic structure. Unless you remove nonbasic goods from the marketplace completely, you won't get rid of marketing. Capitalism goes after our drive to want things and show off status. People in the Scandinavian or Nordic countries are much less materialistic; you don't see the same spending mentality in those countries.

The irony is that the USA and western European systems aren't truly capitalist, they just feign it.  In a truly capitalist system, the 2008 crash would've sunk most of the banks who had recklessly been giving out mortgages to anyone who asked - that is the price you should pay for reckless, high risk behaviour under a capitalist model.  However, with the exception of Iceland, the collective governments of the west bailed them out. THIS IS NOT CAPITALISM.     I strongly suspect that film 'the Big Short' was right - the banks knew they would do this, so it wasn't so much that they were ignorant of the coming financial apocalypse but that they simply didn't care because they knew the taxpayer would ultimately bail them out.  Wall St banker types label themselves 'capitalists', but they aren't - if you have the attitude of 'I'm a shark, so I'm going to swim with other sharks and eat smaller fish' that is all well and good.  But, under a TRULY capitalist system, if you screw up in that environment you should get eaten yourself, not be able to beg a bailout and then wander round the corner to another financial institution which, despite your demonstrable incompetence, will hire you because you play golf with its CEO.  And so, with no incentive to change their reckless behaviour in the future, the cycle continues...   A TRULY capitalist system would scare the daylights out of these people because it would force them to face the consequences of their actions and moderate their behaviour accordingly.  That is not to say I would advocate such a system (it would likely give rise other major social issues), but imo it would be better than what we have now - a system which describes itself as capitalist, but is ready to ditch capitalist ideals the moment they threaten the interests of the 1%.

But satisfaction of basic human needs only leads to new needs anyway. Capitalism in that sense is only an outgrowth of human nature. If human nature, under conditions of basic need satisifcation, is simply to want, to desire, it's unclear why Capitalism, specifically under  afree society, isn't better  than the alternative. If my basic human needs are met, and now I want internet, and shitty jobs are required to satisfy that want, and people are free to choose to do or not to do those jobs, I'm not sure what criticism remains that isn't circular? A non-alienating example of such a job would be one where you have some kind of stake in the company, right? In theory, people are free to collectively incorporate and provide those same services. So shouldn't the question really be about why people don't do that? Is it an issue with the system or with people under such a system or even with people as such? Yes, I'm leaving out a lot of details about the real world, but I would argue Marx does the same, leaving out a lot of details about human psychology/ability.   With respect to advertising, I think it can be argued that advertising is one of the necessary costs of privledge, of having more than you 'need.' Sure, it's evil, manipulative, annoying, and so on, but so are all costs. Couldn't one say the same about agricultural pets? If you're able to massively farm, i.e. provide an eco system for pests, one of the costs is in dealing with those pests. In that sense, pests are the price of privledge where the privledge is the ability to produce more food than *one* needs. I don't know how good or bad an anaology that is, but it's at least a spring board.   That said, I agree a better system would be something socialist where basic needs are guranteed and afterwards you can do whatever you want with your money. But that won't eliminate advertising and doesn't invalidate capitalism as a system for satisfying ever-becoming desires.

Everything we on the left do should be in service of the eventual dismantling of capitalism, since capitalism is clearly the greatest enemy of liberation we face today. I support affordable healthcare because it is the right thing to do, and because the fact that your health coverage is tied to your job is just another link in the chain your boss has around your neck. I support civil rights and anti-racist policies because it is the right thing to do, and because the sooner the lower classes stop fighting with each other and unite against their common enemy the better. These reasons are why I support anti-sexist policies as well. I support ending the War on Drugs and prison reform because they are the right things to do, and because for too long these have been the tools the capitalist class use to put down those who threaten them. We can set the stage now, and by a thousand cuts we can bring down the beast without leveling the castle with it.

What I find so baffling about 'combating capitalism' or any other boogie monster is that there seems to be a lot of activists and not a lot of well... new politicians to replace the old ones. Recent protests especially in America have been absolutely pathetic on both sides. There's a lot of energy in the crowd of teens with bike-locks and scarves on their faces who like to counter protests veterans having a nice leisurely walk in the park with a few signs, but nobody to actually take responsibility for the change that they're going ape shit for. It feels like it's bratty kids doing what they learned to do at home to get what they want; throw a tantrum, but now they're no longer kids and the rules of the games are different. The youth of today don't seem to have any idea how good we have it with a capitalist system, there are plenty of people alive to tell of alternative systems and how it feels to live in the Soviet Union for example, not a lot of countries bordering Russia calling for revolution of capitalism any time soon.  For general purpose media where the subject is critique of capitalism or just capitalism there should really be a lot of caveats about how literally almost every positive thing about our society is also the product of capitalism, if you want to appear in good faith, not just spout 'work sucks lmao'. Taking good things for granted and then complaining at the few icky bits isn't helpful or even thought provoking for most, it's just plain misleading.  I think especially the American capitalism based system has a problem with longevity if there is too much swing towards one party in political power for too long, but other than that it's pretty freaking sweet compared to alternatives. I think the way forward is tweaks to it rather than a complete revolution and a dice roll on the viability of the new system with millions of deaths as a consequence of rolling snake eyes.

Love your videos. Glad to see a topic I finally disagree with. I think being a more social-politics oriented channel, you looked at this issue of a sociologist. I think from an economist's point of view, some aspects of capitalism begin to make more sense. (Although one could argue that the idea of an economist comes from capitalism, yada yada yada)  When rich people buy expensive things, that money doesn't just vanish. It's not like they're just offering it up to the lizard gods as a fuck you to all the poor people in the world. When a billionaire buys a million dollar boat, they provide income to the people that built the boat, the people that designed the boat, the people that built the electrical equipment inside the boat, and that money flows through all those companies down to the employees who never even came within a mile of the boat. That boat creates jobs for a possible captain and crew.  The basic flaw in capitalism is that because of its nature, some people will be forced to bear the brunt of consumerism, and endlessly want for things they don't need/can't afford.  I would say in a more refined world of capitalism, everyone would be given the education and tools to find a career that fulfills them. I think with the advent of the internet, we are approaching a world where that is becoming increasingly possible for the driven and motivated. With all the resources available online for cheap or free, the barriers to success are becoming smaller.  A non-capitalistic society is a big change, and I think it's great to hear criticisms of the system. However, I think an entire shift in how our world operates would, in the end, do more harm than good in the lives that it would destroy.

I agree that pragmatism and realism is part of good socialist political strategy, but I'm very disappointed Contra limited her analysis of capitalism to whatever is inside the imperial borders of the USA. Improving conditions and redestributing the wealth inside the empire, without having a plan for the phasing out of the exploitation of the world's southern hemisphere, which to a large extent produces this wealth in the first place, is just a kinder global imperialism. It makes the global proletariat's plight a fair price to pay for local equality. This is where the pragmatism of economic policy-oriented state-level strategy comes up against the most basic principle of solidarity, and where radical socdems like Sanders and Cortez will probably show their willingness to chauvinistically continuing the status quo outside local borders. A lot of these criticisms are valid. However, they elide the fact that capitalism is responsible for lifting the whole world out of poverty at an unprecedented rate. The unfortunate reality is that the Pareto Principle dictates that the more wealth being generated consequently gives rise to greater inequality. While this might provide an objective rise in the standard of living it's also at odds with the Gini Coefficient, which is a statistical measure of inequality with a strong positive correlation with civil unrest and violent crime. As a species we dislike wealth, because we'll always feel we aren't getting enough of it, that we're entitled to some arbitrary portion. It's genuinely a shame.

As a capitalist I disagree with you on some things but you bring up good points and are well explained. Also the production value is awesome. I think my biggest issue with socialism is nation wide socialism in a place as vast as America. Take New Jersey which has a large autistic population, given a free healthcare system for example, it  would be better donating money towards that whilst other states may not. A federal government would have a hard time adapting to that, and the US federal government is way to hard to make not corrupt whilst you can treat states in a more capitalistic manner. So if for example my state PA goes corrupt we can move and not pay taxes to the corrupt government there.  As much as a capitalist as I am I will be the first to admit it has flaws, and as many pro capitalists have pointed out, capitalism should not be equivalent to anarchy. Places like medicine and education (department of education is an example of money buying politics) should be regulated.  Either way I hope we can find a middle ground that can take the best of both systems and build a society that is truly fair, disciplined, and allows for the most opportunity, cheers. There is something about the statement 'capitalism relies on the state to exist' (paraphrasing) that feels like a disingenuous characterization of reality. In order for capitalism to exist in its purest and most potent form, the only laws required are 1.) you can own things, and 2.) you cannot steal.The resulting hierarchies that emerge out of what is effectively just (anarchy + property rights) is a testament to the usefulness of markets as a decentralized strategy for producing an unexpectedly just society, relatively speaking. Those at the top of the hierarchies produced by markets typically only seek to MINIMIZE the power of the state via attempts at deregulation and lowering of taxes. The extent to which such entities are willing to use the state in order to bolster their position in the hierarchy (via mechanisms such as patent law) would only ever be described as an anti-capitalist departure from free markets.  Communism and socialism, however, derive the entirety of their power to produce hierarchies (or lack thereof) from the authority of the state. This is because socialism and communism are prescriptive in the outcomes they seek to produce, whereas capitalism is not. If the resulting structure of a capitalist society is that all the individuals at the top of the hierarchy were to radically redistribute their wealth a la Bill Gates or Warren Buffet, this would be no more or less capitalist than were they to double down on maximizing their position in the hierarchy.  It therefore felt as though what you meant to say was not that capitalism is dependent on the state to exist, but rather that the avenue via which you'd like to COMBAT capitalism is dependent on the state. There is a cynical argument that could be made that you willfully associated the market authority of successful capitalists with the authority of the state in an attempt to utilize a general anti-authoritarian sentiment that people have, but any further departure from free markets would only be done under an increase in authoritarian policy. I'm not saying this is either a good or a bad thing, I just don't feel like it was characterized correctly.

This is my opinion: Capitalism has a lot of problems, but it is the best system we have. There are just no good alternatives. Communism and socialism obviously don't work (and yes they do NOT work, if you want to argue with that point feel free to do so and I'll try and convince you otherwise), so we are left with only one economic doctrine. Of course, pure laissez faire capitalism is just as bad as communism since we end up with a sort of social darwinism, where monopolies control the economy and leave everybody else to rot. What we need is capitalism with some trust-busting and big business busting laws, ensuring the free market is not dominated by either the state or huge corporations.  Karl Marx made a lot of good points about pure capitalism, and I would even go as far to say that he was right about it. However, the alternative that he gives is much worse. I mean, ya'll are complaining about hundreds of thousands of people barely scraping by working soul crushing jobs, while in the Soviet Union and Communist China millions of people were dying of starvation or being deported to prison camps. We must find a balance between pure capitalism and socialism, where there is a prosperous free market with plenty of competition and no dominating corporations. Of course, that's not an easy thing to accomplish.

You raise good points, a quote I find hilarious from the Communists is this. 'They will sell us the noose we use to hang them!' Capitalism has always been profit first, with things like the Trading Companies of the Colonial Era being some of the more powerful Entities next to Governments. Current Day economic Situations is made worse because, sadly, the average Citizen ALLOWS themselves to be manipulated by adds. I don't mean this in the way of saying 'OH, I'm smarter than you and make better choices' I buy Plastic Crack (40k Miniatures) for Gods sake! But we have to make better choices with our money. I don't rent because I need to save up, I have a plan 5-6 years ahead, I plan on making my own business (small of course) and all that stuff, but the main disadvantage the Common Worker faces is that he is alone, while the wealthier businesses have ENTIRE TEAMS to cut through the Red Tape. Low skill high Pay Jobs no longer exists, and minimum wage jobs are becoming rarer and rarer. So in my admittedly small experience in the world of economics, there's 2 ways to grow. Work Harder than everyone else, which is how I've been working and has worked out so far. Or create your own business. The third Option is subsistence living which I honestly think could make a comeback at some Point. We must also be willing to sacrifice personal Luxiries. I have an used car, I only buy the clothes I need, and I've used the same phone for 4+ years. I try to cut costs where I can (don't eat out much and try to use as little gas as possible) and I have a growing bank account and still some for my Crack. I understand in the States it's different, but honestly, as long as you work and provide for the Family, living with your parents may well be a necessary step.
Say whatever you want, you have no better alternatives.

Great video, though I feel like describing these as problems with capitalism isn't quite correct. You could imagine a capitalist society where advertising is highly regulated and restricted, where there are strong unions and labor protections making jobs less shitty and less time consuming, where people aren't burdened by student or medical debt, and where mega corporations don't just take everything over. In fact, such societies do exist, such as Sweden and Denmark. They are still capitalist, just a different kind of capitalist. They still have private ownership and distribute a large portion of goods and services through markets. I can get on board with that. That's why I did like the end of this video, where you focused on more practical stuff.

I wasn't really partial to any economic system went I went into college; however, after taking microeconomics, capitalism seems to be the economic system that makes the most sense. I do agree that it has its problems, but socialism causes even more problems and causes more people to be poor. While capitalism produces many poor people, the poorest person under capitalism is richer than the poorest person under socialism, and, ultimately, I think everyone wants the poor to be as well off as possible. I honestly don't think there's any perfect economic system that will resolve poverty, because the root of poverty is not in which economic system we use, but in the tendency of humans to take advantage of other humans. I believe that if humans acted in a moral fashion, any economic system would work; however, since humans are naturally greedy and competitive, an economic system that takes these traits into account is most likely the best one.

Hey, I think you're wrong about adverting. Most adverting is aimed at reaching an audience with certain needs/desires for the service or product, that's why google analytics is so valuable, it lets advertisers target their ads to the people who already want their category of product.   A Tesco ad for pork targeted at a vegan is wasted money and no amount of it is going to persuade them to buy it there. However, a meat eater might choose to go to Tesco next time for that instead of some other store. I hated it but I worked in advertising for years and this is most of what companies do. A pretty small portion outside of premium TV ad space is this sort of basic 'let the people know we exist' sort.  Obviously there is a lot of image creation inside all of that but it's not necessarily lying if companies are policed to make sure they don't (they try all the time anyway) and the presentation of an image isn't necessarily a falsehood but an accurate portrayal of what kind of company you might shop/use/go into business with. And yeah some portion is made by wastes of space trying to convince people they need something totally unnecessary but no one would say clothes, food, furniture, cars and banking is unnecessary (not coincidentally our largest clients). Ultimately the purpose of advertising (theoretically) is to make consumers aware of their choices and present them with more information to make their decisions with, rendering them a more 'rational' consumer though I have no idea if that's actually the case.

Good man. Far right and Far left unites in the shadows of the main discourse over precisely the point of spirit. Though viewed from two different angles, both recognise the spirit. Perhaps the horseshoe theory is somewhat right if we put the human soul there at the end where the two points meet.   Although fascism and communism only see one side of the soul and a new perspective is needed, the liberal capitalist democracy while having the best perspective is also the furthest away, seeing nothing but a foggy reflection of something that then soon enough falls out of collective memory. So it ends up creating a thousand replicas for the satisfaction of the soul, all of which never come close but all of which we keep consuming; for the lack of a better alternative.  We need to envelop the soul again in a syncretic ideology apt for the 21:st century. In doing so we must somehow include the good aspects of capitalism which enabled the engine of individual creativity to sprint away while cleaning it of all the pollution and destruction it creates in the wake of its desperate search for meaning.  (Out of this syncretic movement, discord will erupt and new developments will happen but for a while we need the unification of ideology the way it happened in the late 19th century. We need to form the nexus of a new big bang instead of trying to grasp at these stars that are ever more distant and irrelevant).  PS: I don't think it's reptiles (i.e. evil capitlists) selling you what they want. It's just mostly normal people who saw needs and a way to fulfill them. They just did it better than some other people. In some cases they were corrupt or nepotistic, but wickedness dwells in all classes of people, even you and me. It is the reason for all of these 'needs' is what needs more exploring.

The Lizards comparison is effective (and btw those masks and gloves are of stellar quality) and the prevalence of conspiracy theories needs to be taken seriously. Much of David Icke's audience are people like me who enjoy it 'ironically' because it's like watching a sci fi reality show. However, I sat down with one of his exhaustively long lectures and it was hours before he got to the reptilians. He spent a huge amount of time pointing out problems in society and the despair of the human soul under capitalism that Marx and Contra talk about in this video, with of course some differences and inaccuracies (dear lord the anti-vaxxer shit). Point is, Icke's audience, and almost all conspiracy theories when they're not leftover anti-semitic babble that didn't die with the Nazis, come from the same 'something is wrong and we're being screwed over' feeling. I doubt all of Icke's fans literally believe alien lizards control the world- some definitely do, I've met them, and I've also met ones who just like how he explains what's wrong with the world (when he's not going on about Saturn and connecting every unconnected symbol in the world to it).   The main reason his stuff works is because the workers and common people of capitalist societies are not just alienated from the product of their labor, they're alienated from their rulers. Think about it, how many employees of large companies ever meet the CEO, or anyone directly under him? How many Government employees ever meet the President or the Chiefs of Staff? How many people who don't work in those fields ever meet the people making decisions about the society they live in and how it will treat them? How many people watching TV news meet the people who make it? It's just... there. Close enough to see but far away.   I've lived in America and Australia, and currently as an adult in Aus, we've got some housing issues- namely that millennials can't afford them. We all rent. barely any of us have ever met our landlords. I interviewed for a share house where the landlord was a foreign investor who didn't care what went on in the house as long as he got his money. There are people with enough power to make decisions that affect whether people live or die overnight, like voting against universal healthcare or cutting wages, and they're so far away in a physical sense, and the things they do are so cruel and inhuman that they might as well be alien lizards. We know this ruling class exist, but in the same way we know the moon exists. Or do we? One of the reasons I think the moon landing conspiracy is so alive and well is because almost no one on the planet will ever go there. It's there, it affects us, but it's really far away. So of course when languishing in the shit jobs you never see the product of, you think 'where's this going? Who's directing all of this? How can I know that what I'm told in answer to that is true? Is anyone directing this at all? If they are, how can they be human and create such a hell for us and gilded palaces for them?'   Of course, they must be Lizards. Because no human can be that bad.   Trouble is, they can. And they are. And they're capitalists. The worst people most of us will never meet.   Oh and before it's pointed out, yes the Reptillian stuff (although it is literal space aliens in Icke's beliefs) does have roots in anti-semitic conspiracy theories, and Icke does reference the protocols of the elders of zion, yet that has almost no effect on why people are drawn to it now, in huge numbers. He's not using them as metaphors for jews, he thinks they are literal space aliens. Yet for people drawn to it, the metaphor for lizards as capitalists works, and the metaphor for lizards as jews, well it might work for the alt-right but that's not really Icke's fanbase, they're more the Jones crowd. Every Icke fan I've talked to starts from the point of 'something is wrong and society is killing us' and it comes back to that. But we never meet the people who are killing us. So maybe they are lizards.

4:54 ''I'm really more of a pursuit of individual happiness person''. This contradicts everything you say about capitalism. Because a world without capitalism is a world without money. A world where people live in small communities, in rural or semi-rural areas, work together to produce what they need (and simply what they need), in a permacultural philosophy (recycling everything, not wasting anything), respecting mother nature, etc. It's a world where only the community has any importance, individual happiness is not a goal. See, socialism works!' but in fact, every single western country, including the scandinavian ones use the capitalist economic system, not a socialist one, they simply regulate it well and tax it heavily to provide a strong welfare system, however it is still a capitalist system as the means of production is still privately owned. You still have consumerism, you still have millionaires, you still have greedy executives, but these things don't bother people because their basic needs ARE provided for and their rights have proper protections.   The main problem in the US isn't capitalism itself, it's the corruption of capitalism and your government caused by the lack of regulation to prevent these things. What you have is much closer to corporatism, masquerading as capitalism, and honestly at this point its gone so far that it's going to be very hard to change that short of a revolution, which is why I understand the appeal for socialist and fascist revolutionaries on both sides of the spectrum, but I'm afraid if either of those things came to pass it may end up only making things worse, history is pretty clear on that, fighting a revolution just in the name of reforming your corporatism into social democracy capitalism on the other hand, while in my opinion it being the best option(although, I object to bloody revolutions wherever plausible), is unrealistic as well, because it's hard to create a revolution out of such a mild ideology. People want to flock to extreme ideologies, which is what tends to cause the problems.  In conclusion, the US is kind of fucked, but I just urge you to remember, that you're still a first world nation and that as bad as the problems might seem right now they CAN get alot, alot worse just by you trying to do something about it. That's not to say that you shouldn't, but you should exercise extreme caution.

I remember the first time I truly started to despise capitalism was when I got a job working in a makeup factory. All employees were on a rotation so I was never on the same line twice in a row, but at least once a week I'd get put on the line responsible for producing Cover FX foundation. The rate at which we produced the foundation was overwhelming, usually averaging out to one piece produced every 3 seconds. I remember this line specifically because it was the only line where I ever saw the product in stores, where it would sell for around $50. Since I was paid minimum wage ($14 CAD) this meant I would need to work 4 hours to be able to buy something I made every 3 seconds.

'End Capitalism.' Yeah. Yeah, that's some plan. Given that capitalism is just the set of behaviors that emerge from a system in which property rights are protected (i.e. people and groups of people are allowed to own things, and the government enforces contracts and punishes things like theft and fraud), 'ending' capitalism can mean all sorts of things. Anti-trust laws, prohibitions against banks printing their own currency, and the criminalization of drug sales and ownership are already common anti-capitalist laws (i.e. laws that abrogate certain forms of freedom of ownership). So when you say you want to 'end capitalism', that's not a very clear statement until you say which additional types of ownership you want to restrict or prohibit. Like, should people not be allowed to own things jointly (i.e. no corporations)? Do you want only the government to be allowed to own land and buildings? What about other objects like factory equipment, printing presses, dump trucks, jack-hammers, normal hammers, clothing, food, and photographs? Is there still money? Are people allowed to lend? Is there a limit to how much an individual is allowed to own?  'Ending capitalism' really means ending freedom of ownership (to at least one extent or another), and I'm really curious to know which specific freedoms advocates of ending capitalism want to do away with and why. (Maybe the freedom to form employer-employee relationships, if those are viewed as always exploitative?)

I watched a video recently by Knowing Better entitled 'The Dirtiest Words in Economics' I didn't find them in there. For me the dirtiest words would have to be 'Primitive Accumuilation' aka for Marx 'the social division of labour' but a better interpretation is 'state sponsored organised crime'. If one goes back to the beginning of Capitalism or to its invention the 'invisible hand of the market' was insufficient for the conditions necessary for capitalism to take seed. Far from the 'laissez-faire' approach the government took a hands on approach. New legal frameworks became the tools to enforce the changes in society. It became legalised violence because the very astute folks in England preferred a life of free time than the possession of manufactured goods. They could not be persuaded to go into wage-labour.  Capitalism and the 'economic rationality' that the state adopted was not just about kicking the people off their traditional lands and into factories and jobs. Resources taken other than land included self-representation, art, methods of using plants, sources of water, intellectual property rights the list just goes on... For an honest description of this read Sir James Steuart's 'An Inquiry into the Principles of Political Economy'. Unlike the apologist John Adams who skips over it, the brutal reality is written in this book.  Edit: Whoops... Of course I meant Adam Smith and his 'The Wealth of Nations... ' and not John Adams. These mistakes tend to happen when I go on a ramble.

I honestly think welfare capitalism is the way forward, the most I would condone is social democracy but socialism is bullshit. Socialism doesn't work for 2 main reasons in my opinion:  1) People are lazy, they are not out for the good of humanity and it would be a large ask for everyone to band together and behave selflessly for the good of the race. People have a hard time doing that now when there are a million and one ways to make money in a capitalistic society, so I don't see the overwhelming amount of people doing it out of the goodness of their hearts.  2) Another main flaw I see in your approach is what do we define as a standard of living which is acceptable for someone who has done little to contribute. In my opinion, basic (and good) education, accessible higher education (not free), accessible healthcare (again not free), freedom of speech and affordable housing. What many people, albeit not all, ask for on the left is what advertisement has lead them to want. I'm from dead on centre of the middle class, my family works for what it has and I am happy we are rewarded for it but we still put in hours at work and develop ourselves within our family to make sure we can have finer things. We could equally make less of a contribution and lead a less extravagant life - and by that I mean eating out less, not $2000 on a new computer (we ain't got caviar money lol).  I agree that some people get too much money, I agree that higher education is too high, and I agree that we need to look after people where we can, but socialism is not the answer. Ultimately, a lot of people in high paying positions worked their assess off to be there and you have people like Bill Gates and Elon Musk pouring their money back into good causes. Capitalism works, but it needs a certain amount of regulating which I think would be offered by welfare capitalism.  Just my two cents, I appreciate the video and the points made.

That 'we are all autonomous individuals making rational choices for our own well-being' is not, and has never been a 'fundamental assumption of capitalist society.' This is like a caricature of capitalism being regurgitated by an 8th grader who's been told too many times they're beyond their years by lefty parents.  While capitalism, vis-a-vis free market economics, requires a respect of bodily autonomy and autonomy in the sense of freedom of choice and freedom of voluntary association, it does not treat individuals as insular, but in fact emphasizes how we benefit both ourselves and others through specialization, which comes alongside increasing interdependence commensurate to the level of specialization we achieve.   It does not assume that we make rational choices all the time--on the contrary, it emphasizes that individual values and preferences are subjective, and do not always conform with the values and preferences that authorities or majorities would consider to be rational, like maximizing one's well-being, long-term happiness, or financial gain. Its main insight is that because of this fact, these is so much information about how scarce resources can be optimally allocated to meet as many human desires as possible which remains trapped and dispersed at the individual or even subconscious level that it's impossible to conceive of a managed system that can credibly be expected to meet human desires and improve human welfare more efficiently than the imperfect laissez faire system of letting people make their own sometimes-irrational decisions in pursuit of their own happiness and values. The laissez faire system allows that essential information about subjective individual preferences to be communicated throughout society via stigmergy while a managed system tries to pretend that this information doesn't even matter, and thus ends up causing huge economic disruptions and malinvestments that harm the most vulnerable in society (at the shallow end,) or ends up miserably failing to efficiently allocate even the most basic resources for their most basic functions in society, causing mass deprivation and starvation (at the deep end.)

A response in five parts to What's Wrong with Capitalism Alternate video title - You are a victim with no responsibility for your own actions Chapter 1 alternate title - You are a victim of capitalism Natalie says young people have an experience of a 'capitalist malaise' in this country.  A malaise is 'a general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness whose exact cause is difficult to identify.'  Natalie implies that citizens of socialist countries do not experience malaise.  This is true.  The reason for this is in the definition of the word.  In socialist countries, historically speaking, feelings of discomfort, illness and unease have a precise and obvious cause, namely, the government that is oppressing them and taking away their freedom every day of their lives.   The malaise that young people experience in America is the terrifying freedom they have over their own lives and the concomitant responsibility for the choices they make as citizens of a free society.  What is Natalie's solution?  Take away our freedom!  It is true that this will remove the feelings of malaise young people face, but it is at the expense of the freedom we all enjoy.  This antidote comes in two parts; stupidity and evil.  The stupid aspect of socialism is ignoring the overall benefits to society brought about by capitalism and the ridiculously great quality of life we enjoy in this country when compared to most of the world, particularly evidenced by the high income Americans have, and the ability for all people to make good economic choices and succeed in our country.  The evil part of socialism is attempting to deny freedom to the population as a whole because some people are terrified of their freedoms.  The result of socialism is that all people in a socialist society are dragged down into a common misery from which they cannot rescue themselves.  While freedom is scary, oppression (dictator socialism) or infantilization (nanny state socialism) are scarier to the intelligent mind and the independent spirit.  Please don't trade uneasiness about your freedom for oppression or infantilization.

Part 2: Chapter 2 alternate title - You are a victim of the man who pays your bills Natalie says your unhappiness in life is due to your shitty job.  Guess what?  If you have a shitty job, GET A NEW ONE!  Start a business.  Become a Youtuber.  Get an education.  The hypocrisy found in Natalie's view expressed on a Youtube video is rich.  How does Natalie earn income?  From Youtube.  How does Youtube pay her?  From advertising revenue.  What is the third chapter of her video about?  The evils of advertising!!!  Come on sheeple, just think logically for ten seconds of your life about this.  Natalie uses capitalism to enrich herself and enjoys the benefits of capitalism (Domino's pizza, Kate Spade shoes and income from clicks on her video) while railing against capitalism.  L...O...L.  Remember that thing we talked about in part 1 about living in a free society?  MONETIZE IT LIKE NATALIE DOES!  Use it to better your circumstances.  Do you have interests, talents, intelligence?  Monetize it LIKE NATALIE DOES.  Educate yourself.  Make yourself valuable to society and society will repay you.  If you already have an education but your degree is in a useless field, get a better education that actually assists you in finding gainful employment.  Ask any of the Chinese, Russians and North Koreans who FLED their socialist utopias to come to America and enjoy freedom how much dignity they found in the labor they were assigned without choice by their authoritarian governments.  Take charge of your situation and better your own life.  It's your freedom and your right.

Part 3:  Chapter 3 alternate title - 'You are a victim of advertising' Natalie says you are a victim of the advertisements you are bombarded with on a daily basis.  This claim is almost too dumb to warrant a response.  First of all, you are personally responsible for your own consumer choices in a capitalist state.  If you squander your money on Domino's pizza and Kate Spade shoes instead of taking care of your essential needs, you will suffer.  This is the danger of living in a free society.  But, you are responsible for making good choices with your money.   Obviously the Domino's shtick is meant to be funny, but the unfunny aspect of it is that the $17 that virtually all Americans have to spend on great things like Domino's pizza and lava cakes (thanks to capitalism) is equal to the TOTAL DAILY MEDIAN INCOME OF AN ENTIRE FAMILY LIVING IN THE SOCIALIST UTOPIA OF CHINA.  If China had spent their time modernizing and fostering an efficient economy after their 'successful' (according to Natalie) revolution instead of destroying their economy by murdering every intelligent, free-thinking or spiritual person in their entire country INCLUDING MANY PRINCIPLED COMMUNISTS (Cultural Revolution, Great Leap Forward; look them up), then Chinese families could afford Domino's pizza with a lava cake, too.  Thank you capitalism! Secondly, Natalie implies that socialist countries don't have advertising campaigns.  This is false.  They do have advertising campaigns, nowadays and in the past.  There is advertising in socialist countries nowadays because socialist countries are DESPERATELY TRYING TO INTEGRATE CAPITALISM INTO THEIR ECONOMIES!  Why?  Because capitalism enriches the lives of individuals and enhances societies.  So now let's ask, why didn't socialsim have advertising in the past?  Historically, there was only one type of advertising allowed.  Every Russian school had pictures of Stalin and every Chinese school had pictures of Chairman Mao in every classroom.  Every child was required to worship these people under threat of death or enslavement for life. Party banners were hung on every street corner so that while you were wallowing in your misery (too hungry and oppressed to experience malaise), you could see on every wall and street corner at the propaganda, I mean advertising, and remember who put you in your sorry situation.   Why didn't socialist countries advertise consumer products?  I would imagine it was because when you're struggling to obtain the basic necessities in life like food, clothing and freedom, the dictatorship ruling over you didn't want you to think about all the other great things you were missing out on as well.

Part 4: Chapter 4 alternate title - 'Victims' address their 'abusers' Natalie cites a study that shows that the majority of people under 30 do not support capitalism and that therefore the evil capitalist overlords who provide most of the goods, services and jobs in our society should fear for their lives and futures.  Yes, young people 'educated' in our high schools and universities have a hard time understanding economics.  Eckonommics is hared.  Unfortunately for socialists, after two decades, many of the young foolish failures she is speaking to will become wiser, middle-aged successes, primarily BECAUSE of capitalism.  When Americans succeed in life under the wonder that is capitalism, many of them stop thinking like victims and reject liberalism.  The hippies and far left anarchists of the 1970's are the voters who rejected Hilary and Bernie's leftist agenda and put Donald Trump in office, precise BECAUSE they got over their victim mentality and succeeded in this country.  Look at voting demographics.  Young foolish people support the left.  Older wiser people support the right.  But you don't need to be (or stay) foolish just because you are young.  You can get wiser right now and find success before you reach age 50.  Take responsibility for your life and your choices.  Don't be a victim forever.

Just gonna get my bias out of the way, I'm quite conservative.  Social inequality (hierarchy) has existed in human society since the invention of agriculture. This moment in history also is where the concept of private property starts. I grow all this food, more than I can eat myself, but that doesn't mean you get to piggy back off my labor. But if you give me something I want, maybe a nice ceramic bowl, I give you some of what I grow. That is the beginning of free trade and labor specialization.  I see government as the nonfarmers banding together and robbing the farmer of what he grew.   To attempt to stop this cycle I feel you have one of two options. Remove labor specialization and return our civilization back to a huntergatherer society where everyone did the same job and there was no social inequality or hierarchy or try to force us all to be perfectly equal through massive government tyranny.   There are social hierarchies and that's not going to change any time soon, but whereas in the past these social structures were enforced through divine right or rank of birth at least capitalism attempts to instead replace those hierarchies with ones created through meritocracy so that the position your in is largely the result of your own actions.  We traditional conservatives also recognize that materialism and consumerism is not a substitute for happiness or spiritual fulfillment. This is why we put our stock in the nuclear family, the local community, and our religion.

Electoral politics are generally useless without a strong social movement to put pressure on it so that the right the people want to defend are actually protected.  Considering how the western world transitionned from feudalism to capitalism (With the steps in between), I observe that the bourgeois class existed before the system that put them into power. They used the areas of economy that were not that much controled by the nobility (notably trade, and banking) to gain economical power. They then gradually gained influence in ideology during the Lumieres and finally took complete political power in the early XIXth century, the era being the one at the genesis of our modern bourgeois nation-state.   From this observation, I conclude that a 'Revolution' is a process rather than an event, a process that needs a myriad of different actions that intersect with each others. I would say that these actions are mainly divided into three categories.   ->Strategies of education ->Strategies of construction ->Strategies of destruction.  Strategies of education are lecture groups, propaganda, visibility protests (protests that need a great amount of people and that are mainly peaceful as to attract the public eye), experimentation of the other two categories and stuff like your videos.  Strategies of construction are all the actions that are done to establish new alternatives. Cooperatives, helping community groups and social services, eco-responsible initiatives etc.   Strategies of destruction are the ones that are aimed at state decisions. They include precisely selected targets like government or corporate office being utterly destroyed repeatedly (rather than just smashing anything that fall under our hands), cops being resisted by large groups of people vith non-lethal (and later, lethal according to the context) force, and sabotage of unpopular projects like pipelines.   Without education, construction remains the fact of marginal communes that breeds sectarism and are ignored by the masses and destruction is viewed as terrorism  Without construction, education remains merely theory nobody cares about an destruction does not support the people doing it and as militant forces tire, the state does not, counting on its seemingly unlimited ressources, or if we ever triumph anyways, let us in ruins without having any foundation to build upon. (I know Durruti talked about not being afraid of ruins, but we still must be organised to build afterwise, like the spanish were)  Without destruction, education is just ideology, and construction is either absorbed by the system, or destroyed by the competing forces of capitalism, like a pipeline would devastate the eco-system near a network of ecological communes or a certain type of cooperatives being attacked by new state regulation orchestrated by corporate greed and the need to bring people back in line.

The problem isn't with capitalism. Or in theory, any other economic system, though socialism has never worked without devolving into tyranny. The problem is people, plain and simple. Too many think if we can just implement a better or supposedly perfect government or economy, a proverbial better mouse trap, people will become better. Or at least have their worst demons curtailed.   Thousands of years of human history has proven nothing externally will make people behave better. Humans were made to game any and all systems. Most people are rebels at heart, and run counter to ANY system just to be stubborn. If we had Heaven, Utopia or Nirvana here and now, there would still be a significant number of folk that would fight it and attempt to overthrow it.  Too many prefer a Hell just so they can rule, rather than be content to serve one another in Heaven.  Only a change within each individual to live the Golden Rule, to be kind, compassionate, honest, etc. will make a better society and world. Anything else external always involves force, by the law, tax, fine, jail, and gun, to treat people as a herd to keep in check.  Even the framers of the Constitution knew and admitted that only a virtuous people would make our nation work, that freedom is fragile, becasue over time people can be free to choose to do the same stupid, selfish stuff and lead them back into misery.  I know I'll get the response, 'Well, what shall we do? Nothing?' My answer is focus on yourself being a better person first. Stop trying to be the manager of the world, and just manage yourself. Pushing for one ideology or politcal party as the 'cure' for our ills is often a distraction so we don't have to look at ourselves and deal with our own flaws.
