Things are designed to be useful. It's a myth that things are designed with planned obsolescence in mind. Pick a product. Any product. A lot of extremely smart, hardworking and dedicated people have hired even more smart, industrious and dedicated people to research and develop the product to be better if an analogue exists, or they make a unique thing like an IPhone and then continue to improve it.  You don't throw away old IPhone because mean people made it bad, but because smart, hardworking and dedicated people have made iPhone 2 that made the original look bad.  Why are people making up things like an iPhone? Because some think that other people will want it more than the money they have saved by working themselves. What is work in today's society? Work is voluntary service of the community unread the leadership of a person brave, smart and insightful enough to save his money and invest it in his new product or service. What is this product or service? Something the leader perceives his wider community will value and want.  This leader becomes an entrepreneur that starts a new business. When the business develops big enough so that the original creator cannot handle the increased demand for his service or product, he hires more people. The entrepreneur pays people to do something the community wants.  When you get your pay, it is a certificate that you have served your fellow men. The more people value your skill, service or product, the more money people are freely willing to pay for it. The less people you serve and the less people value your contribution, the less money you get. There is no single person making up prices. The market, composed of the community of people, determine how much they are willing to pay. No one is forcing anyone to pay for anything. Capitalism is predicated on mutual satisfaction. You value iPhone more than you value money you have earned, and Apple values your money more than the iPhone they have sold you. Both parties are better off after the transaction.  You offer a service or a product and if the people are willing to pay for it, you'll become one of the few successful people, brave enough to try to start a business. Most others will either charge too much or offer a service or product that too few people value, and so they will go out of business. This is how in a direct sense, the community directly rewards or punishes different companies, goods or services. Prices aren't arbitrary. They are the exact lowest amount most people are willing to pay, and the exact least amount that still makes the seller better off too. In this way, and this way only- both the buyer and the seller are happy with their transaction.  It is only after the business is sought after enough, that more people can be hired to perform vital tasks in order to provide this good or service or to improve it.  Young people go to University so that they may develop higher skills so that entrepreneurs would be more likely to hire them. University training also increases students chances that they will be compensated higher for their contribution to society as well as makes very special few bold and daring individuals start their own company, service or product. No company started out big. Steve Jobs and Bill Gates started from a garage, while working and sleeping in their parent's basement. Only after a gargantuan amount of work and time invested have they developed into behemoths we know today.  People advocating for communism fail to see fragility of the early entrepreneur's problems and only wish to seize the company once an incredibly dedicated and clever person or people have brought it up from the ground. They confuse worker's contribution to the owners. The owner is the visionary. The person who has put blood and sweat into making the company grow. The worker enjoys stable pay regardless if the company is successful or not. They enjoy fruit regardless of the company's success. The owner enjoys success and profit if, and _only_ if he manages to serve big enough chunk of the community in such a way that they are more likely to re-use or recommend it to their friends and family.  If you think iPhone or any other good or service is far too expensive, feel free to start your own company that would charge a more fair price. Because this happens literally every day, it's very hard for anyone to charge too much or offer unfairly low wage for the workers. Any other business with a better plan, product or service will steal both the workers who will flock to work for higher wage, as well as customers who will want to purchase the better product.  This way, the market- made of the people in the community- together decide what they value. Those companies, goods and services flourish, while the others, go out of business and fail. It is only the most compassionate, fairest and least corrupt business prevail. Greed is the opposite of capitalism. Greedy people who charge more than something is worth go out of business fastest of all. It is only those who offer the most, for the least- that manage to prosper. When you said 'the real surge and support for a white ethnic homeland' and showed a video of charlottesville on the screen, it really bothered me. The whole charlottesville 'protest' was about preserving history, and keeping up a statue. It has nothing to do with preserving or establishing a 'white ethno-state.' The man the statue is of (which is still up in charlottesville btw) Robert E. Lee, commander of the northern army of Virginia. People hate the statue because Lee was a commander for the confederacy; which automatically makes people assume he was pro-slavery.  But, this is wrong. Robert E Lee inherited slaves from his father, but then freed them because he did not believe it was right. At one point Lee was approached by the Union army to become a general for them, but Lee decided to fight for his brothers and his homeland instead, because he grew up in the south and knew there was nothing better than the hills and streams he knew and loved. Here in Virginia, Lee is a symbol of patriotism and freedom, not of slavery and hatred; and certainly not of an 'ethno-state.' I know many people who went to the torch march in charlottesville, and they are just regular educated college kids and parents who are tired of the far-left trying to bury any part of history they find offensive. Now, I am an emt and was there at the actual protest administering care to people, and let me tell you that everything AFTER the torch march was just a clusterfuck of paid protesters and bullshit. I don't think either side even knew what they were doing there.  What a cruel thing war is... to fill our hearts with hatred instead of love for our neighbors. - Robert E. Lee

I am not a fan of socialism. I've thought about the issues with capitalism (and have read about how things work for a while) and find that the biggest issue we have is that there's a massive difference between large multi-national companies and everyone else (that is to say, mid-level sized corporations and everyone smaller in scale). Once you get massive enough that you're either a monopoly or part of an oligarchy, there's really only one game: perpetuating short term goals that completely ignore the long term health of a company because of the shareholders' interests.   This explains why the second largest pharmacy in the world (Rite Aid) was trying to sell itself to the largest one in the world, why T-Mobile's been trying to swallow Sprint or merge with AT&T. It also is one of the primary drivers of the 2008 market crash. If you reward short sighted aims, unchecked growth (Lewis Black's bit about a Starbucks literally across the street from a Starbucks comes to mind), and taking advantage of deregulation in order to commit crimes (aka: 2008 market crash), that's pretty much a recipe for fucking over people. Even with colleges, there's a massive bloat to the administrative costs, pushing costs up. If you want more profit, you monopolize and create more things to charge for.  To me, there's more of a cultural issue than one with the economic model. I see an over reliance on the pure math in economics with an absolute disdain for ethics in economics as the focal point, as it spills over into politics with the campaign contributions in order to get their way. And since the name of the game is money in politics, there's no way a large corporation can lose unless their candidates get out contributed by the opposition. But, if people think more ethically, then I don't think the emphasis on math will be so much of a problem, particularly when it comes to the term 'regulation'. I see minimal regulation as a means to just give a framework of what's not permissible. So long as you don't do that, you're good to go. But, that's not good enough to corporations because of the 'barriers to profit' that they bring.

The reason why capitalism sucks is because we don't live in a free market capitalist society, but a bastardized corporatist, neocon/neoliberal version of capitalism. The reason why everything costs so much and the reason why jobs are becoming worse and are decreasing in numbers is because of increased regulation which drives up costs for businesses. The reason why so many jobs are going oversees is because in foreign countries, their governments aren't hostile to entrepreneurs. And as for why only giant corporations are doing well is because they are the only ones who can afford to pay for these regulations, effectively eliminating their competition (it explains why most giant corporations support more regulations and not fewer). In a free market capitalist society, we wouldn't have these problems because the Berlin walls that trap small business owners from having a chance against the massive corporations wouldn't exist. America would be much better, and people would be much richer, if we had maintained a free market system as well. In other words, you hate corporatism, not capitalism.

What you're complaining about isn't capitalism, it's greed and gluttony preying on envy. Its just as you said, big business creating needs so their products can fill those needs. The threshold for what someone wants and someone needs is very subjective.  Ice cream is a good example. Yes, it's food, and people need to eat, but ice cream can't sustain someone. It's value is purely that it tastes good, and people want to enjoy something that just tastes good sometimes at the expense of their health. Is that wrong? Should someone not provide ice cream to fill the need?  Capitalism is what allows someone who identifies people's desire to have ice cream to open up a store, provide a desired product or service and make a living for themselves (and others by providing jobs).  Evil big business becomes big because they provide a good or service that people want, and they do it well. You can complain all day long about Wal Mart (for example) but the fact is that people wouldn't shop there if Wal Mart didnt provide desirable poducts and services compared to the alternatives. If you hate Wal Mart then you're welcome to not give them your money or start a business that does it better than Wal Mart.   If you want to make the argument that big business can get bed with government to put their thumb in the scale against other businesses that aren't as predatory, then I'm 100% with you. Thing is, that's not capitalism, that's cronyism. And bigger government just empowers those businesses even more.  I love the format of the videos though. Well done!

One thing we can work towards is raising awareness of and support for Labor Rights. 'Union' is a dirty word in many states and communities, mainly because Republicans have successfully re-branded them in most people's minds as corrupt, unnecessary, and/or harmful to workers. But without collective bargaining, the exploitation of the working class will continue unchecked.  We need to be singing from the hills and mountaintops that Unions are needed to protect the rights of the American Worker. You aren't being paid enough to live because there's no Union to fight for a living wage. You got laid off or fired for no reason because you have no Union to fight for your right to work. You can't speak out against your shitty, abusive boss because you have no Union to back you up. You need to Unionize to get what you need from your job, because they won't give it to you on their own.

See, the thing is: Communism offers a different method, but will net you the exact same results. If not ever so slightly worse. The problem isn't capitalism in itself. The problem is de facto aristocracy. Any system in which trade of resources occurs is a capitalist system. That includes most communist systems, unless you outright ban... Trade. And without trade, you cannot get what you want; only that which is allotted to you by an authority (which, make no mistake, will be that system's de facto aristocracy).  Whether the method of enslavement is necessary consumption of goods (rent, mortgage, education and Insurance hikes, as well as food price hikes and inflation that does not adjust with cost of living) without the ability to opt out or gather enough wealth to progress on the ladder (wage slavery, in short) or assigned labour, the effect is ultimately the same for the largest amount of people.  Capitalism, to the extend that it occurs today, is... Bad, but at least can get to choose what products we spend our meagre Leisure allowance on. Granted, that is mostly because money is smaller than vouchers. Under capitalism, you can ensure more individual freedoms and rights than under communism. Which is kind of a big deal for me.

So, there is no question that there are some major issues in our capitalist society, but at the same time this is one of the few societies throughout human history that has brought so many people out of poverty and given them access to education and healthcare. We have the freedom to love who we wish and express ourselves in like manner as would make us happy.   One of the main issues with the views presented here is the lack (or at least seeming lack) of appreciation for what western society has built. Just destroying what we have is only going to bring about far more suffering than we currently have.   Communism has killed millions of people and the argument that it wasn't done right in Soviet Union/China...etc. therefore we must try again, is just making the ideology more important than the people that it should be serving. People must never be a means to and end. People are not expendable. How many more millions of people must die before we can agree that in theory communism can be appealing but in practice it  manifests in tyranny.

I don't think anyone serious really measures well-being in terms of GDP.  Your claim that people are poor off doesn't offer something better.  It's like criticizing cars and telling people that horses work.  Communism has proven it's failures and mixed economies tend to have peoples that are largely decent to one another, which makes capitalism possible in the first place.  You can't run any society without decency and in a culturally diverse nation, many people view decency as an option rather than a personal obligation.  If you screw over a stranger, for instance, it's much different than screwing over your close family members.  Your family holds you accountable for your actions, when a stranger can only have legal or extralegal.  Anyway, back on point --  If you run a society 'from each according to their ability, to each according to their needs' you run into the problem of many people realizing they can just claim to be more needy or more oppressed than the others around them, and getting extra resources for that need.  Also, assuming the society doesn't have an underlying sense of honor, you could just claim your ability is lacking and not have to work as hard because of it.  At that point, the government would force people into work camps (assuming scarcity), ignoring both their abilities and needs, which is really no different than slavery.

Look.. It's just a tricky question. On one hand I believe that business owners no matter how rich they are should be entitled to all of (or at least most of) the money they bring in. Did they not fairly earn the money they made? I'm sure a lot of work goes into the creation and success of major companies, and it's only fair to let them keep what they rightfully earned. If an employer wants to offer me a job, they should be allowed to choose the wage, and if I don't like it then I can just turn it down same as any other mundane agreement. Maybe we should be looking at how our government constantly devalues the dollar and makes what paltry money you do bring in worth much less.  On the other hand a lot of people aren't able to avoid working for someone else as a lot of markets are almost completely cornered by big chain stores like Wal Mart. You can't successfully own as many businesses today as you could in the past so you're forced to work for someone else, and forced to take the wages they give you or starve. Although it's unfair to the business owners who (in most cases) worked hard for their money and deserve to keep at least most of it, they could definitely do without a lot of it and still live much better than %99 of people in the world. Taxing the wealthy can feed the hungry and provide services to people in need while not completely making them poor. However this can lead to outsourcing which does nothing but take jobs away.  They're both unfair to someone, and have clear benefits and drawbacks. You're either punishing the poor for not being good enough to compete, or you're punishing the rich for being too good at competing.

Hey @contrapoints I can empathize with the points in this video but I don't agree with the narrative of 'oppressors' and 'oppressed'. Rather, it's something more like this -- the 'oppressors' are really just the people who are chosen based on their competence and willingness to take on responsibility. Example; I built a company in my 20's after working my ass off for 5+ years working 90 hour weeks while stretching my credit, health, and relationships to the max. After 5 years, for a very short time, I approached the top 10% of American earners with an income of around $100k/yr. I employed about 50 people during that time and worked hard to fulfill their payroll, PTO, health care, and HR related needs. And if I misstepped I'd hear about it pretty damn quick and pay the price. (I guess I was an evil capitalist lizard with slaves?) Anyway, rather than victimizing the workers and blaming the bosses, maybe pay respect and celebrate everyone's hard work and success? I like Jordan Peterson's solution -- bear as much responsibility and suffering as you can to give meaning to your life. If that was valued by both 'oppressors' and 'oppressed' I think this disparagement would vanish.

Here's the issue. You're not basing your points at the correct level of analysis. To critique the overall formula of Capitalism, you have to truly understand what its purpose is, and you do not define that whatsoever. With your shortsighted view of the 'material' that you note yourself very quickly in the video, you fail to critique past that level of analysis at all, you're completely mired in it. You fail to acknowledge 'needs' as a problem expounded outward from the individual and that those 'needs' are not capitalistically imposed by the supposed 'rules' of Capitalism. You can make the joke 'look what capitalism made me do' without realizing that its your capitalist ideal in yourself that allows you to 'do' in the first place. The one thing that capitalism does have, that many on the left seem to throw out the window, is that the mechanism by which it exists, also allows for a juxtaposed system to compete with the entire system itself. The value of economy is what is happening, NOT what people hoard. If I play by the 'open market rules' there are a lot of games that we can play, many of them not so good and extremely exploitative, but just because it allows one to do that, Its a bad idea to further hinder the individual the chance to convince people to play a new game that would be more beneficial for society in general. Capitalism allows the ideas of competent individuals to outshine those worse ideas of others. Legislating into law some sort of framework by which we hand off the competence of the individual to some large overarching structure only act as a hindrance to people who may have the possibility to fix the problems from within the individual and expanding outward into real world manifestation. The only reason you would feel as you do is because you feel your incompetence shining forward in the form of you not having the ability to fix it. You see the capitalist shilling and fail to see that you're just not good enough to beat it, so you need to legislatively impose against the most obvious problems you see. Keep calling yourself an intellectual with all your useless materialist degrees. You just fail to see the point.

im an anarchist and i think you painted an unfair representation of anarchism, maybe not of anarchist, but of anarchism.    While i think anyone would agree we need some sort of plan, i felt it somewhat unfair how you portrayed the anarchist position. It's ironic that you made the joke about how anarchists ask condescendingly what one has read because the one you say you haven't is bakunin. I believe it was bakunin who was a part of the libertarian wing of the Internationale which did have what one could call a plan. not detailed of course thats ridiculous. But they did laid the ground work for what later inspired spanish anarchists to develop anarcho-syndicalism, which i would argue IS the plan.  what i mean to say is that, what the CNT, FAI, and IWW do is create a new world in the shell of the old. we argue that we should create things like workers councils, syndicates, call them what you will, and to have those new institutions that are being created serve as the backbone for the 'new world'. direct action is just the means. you don't need a politician to sign a piece of paper to get shit done, one could just go do it. there are people who organize soccer tournaments without the need of the state they just do it. why not do the same with every other institution of society? Why don't the people in the medical field run and operate the medical field as they see fit? i would argue they are the most qualified to do so.  another thing is when you said that the state is needed to protect capitalism. I completely agree. But i just want to make something clear. typically in my experience i find Marxists argue that the state is an instrument of class rule. So therefore why not create a state that protects the working class? While on the surface this makes sense i don't agree with the initial idea of the state being an instrument of class rule. While under capitalism it is quite clear the state serves their interests, it i think is inaccurate to say the state is an instrument of CLASS rule. Rather I argue the state is an instrument of minority rule, and has developed certain characteristics that help it do just that. centralized and hierarchical. it is for this reason anarchists reject the ML position of creating a 'workers state'. to us that is a contradiction. ultimately the party is going to be the new ruling elite, nothing really changed. so i think its important to know what exactly it is anarchists are arguing for and against.   one last thing. There are many objections marxists make of the anarchist position and i cant really go into detail and explain why i think the things I mentioned, however if you are curious i recommend the Anarchists FAQS, just google em. I think it's part H where they go over Marxists objections to anarchism. Also i recommend Bloodstained 100: years of Leninist counterrevolution. Great book.  great video nonetheless, keep it up!!

Need. What is need really. If we formed our societies based on 'objective' needs then we would have not need to progress further than the state of hunter-gatherers. Why did people need the spear when they could run down their pray? Why did they need the bow when they had the spear. Adverisement can be influential for sure, but to trace the origin of the subjectivity of need, to advertisement and capitalism is simply wrong. You should also define what do you mean by capitalism. Because if you define capitalism as a system of production through the accumulation of capital, then you are just describing every economic system, since like...forever. Let me make an example to prove my point. Lets assume we have an farming society, where than land is the means of production and the people work to sustain  themselves without the accumulation of any capital (aka spare food). Let us say now that this farming community wants to built a school. How to they do that? They can not stop working the land to built the school, not one of them, because they would starve. In order to built that school that need accumulate capital (food) to sustain the workers through the duration of the school's construction. By doing so, they have accumulated capital and have become in every sence of the word, capitlists, and work under a capitalist system.

Good video! You make the basic argument against capitalism very well, and the video is very fun, which is needed considering how many stuffy eggheads you can find talking about this stuff. I can't fully agree with the end of your video though. Tabby's lack of real direction is very common among the left, particularly anarchists, and I agree that it's a very serious problem, but there is a concrete revolutionary solution that doesn't rely on collaborating with the state. It's Protracted People's War (PPW), which is the only warfare strategy never to have been defeated militarily, and I believe the only way to destroy capitalism.  Its principles have been used in countless movements and wars since the success of the Communist Revolution in China, and regardless of how exactly you feel about Mao, the US military heavily studies his military theory, and in declassified intelligence documents, it's very clear that the US views it as a much larger threat to their dominance than anything else. The best thing is, its principles can only be used to the fullest by genuine revolutionaries, because it relies primarily on a large support base among the general population, which a capitalist military can never fully hold onto.  This style of warfare is exactly why the US invasion of Vietnam was repelled, and why the US failed to take over North Korea. Both of these countries are definitely capitalist, but they both successfully used elements of Mao's theory of PPW, and both states at the time enjoyed massive support from their people, with the invasion by western imperialism serving as a unifying force among the population. I believe that similarly, the US has never really won a war since WWII precisely because of the spread of the theory of People's War. Everywhere the US goes, the local peasants and workers are ready to pick up arms, and some group, whether revolutionary or reactionary, is there to lead them into battle.  There are many Maoist revolutionary groups in the world that are already putting the universal parts of Protracted People's War into practice, including quite a few in Europe and the US itself. From what the most organized of these groups say and what you can see in their videos and pictures, it seems they have been quite successful in this as well. There is no peasantry here, so PPW will look quite different in the west, but you only have to look at the recent and historical riots in the US to see how effective poor folks can be even when they're unorganized. Here too, people are ready to take up arms; it's just that the groups that have taken leadership so far have only lead them to the voting booths and to respectability politics, rather than to revolution. I believe that's changing though, as it was in the 60s and 70s with the Black Panthers and the Revolutionary Union/RCP-USA in their heydays.

'Capitalism did X' - No. Capitalism is simply the ownership of private property, i.e you get to keep what you make, and transactions between people have to be voluntary, that is to say you have to consent to any kind of transactions, be that a purchase of some goods or services, or contractually transacting your own labour/ideas/skills for some renumeration/benefits (pay). Such a system efficiently creates products and services that people want, the fact that people want them has nothing to do with capitalism, that's down to whatever value system they subscribe to. Capitalism doesn't fetishize commodities, PEOPLE do, capitalism simply supplies those commodities  where there is demand for them, and makes sure that production of such commodities is done in a voluntary way. I.e you're not forced to work for anyone, you're not forced to hire anyone, it's a free market of people negotiating terms of contracts between them.  Here's a thought, if you don't like your job then leave. Jobs don't oppress people, and employees don't oppress people, you sign a contract voluntarily that dictate the terms of your employment, if you don't like the terms then don't sign. If you want a work force that bucks the trend, where workers don't have to complete with one another because raises and promotions don't have anything to do with the value added to the businesses then start your own competing business and implement those policies on the staff that you hire. What you'll soon find out is that no one with any prospects will work for you for long because their progress doesn't track with the value they add and they'll go to the competition leaving you unable to compete in the marketplace. The very business offering you a job to begin with, continues to exist because they promote the best and keep the businesses innovative and competitive by keeping their prices low and quality high.  We have advertising because people are stupid and buy products they're advertised rather than making rational choices based on quality/cost trade off. It's peoples behaviour that makes advertising a cost efficient enterprise, if people didn't respond to it or they simply blocked it (thanks adblock plus) then that problem would go away naturally. In fact the only way to make it go away otherwise is through the use of force, that is threaten people to not do it via some structure like the state/law. Again you have it backwards, advertising doesn't manufacture desire, people already have the desire for things, what advertising does it notify interested people that your product is available to fit that desire. If you're seeing adverts for things and accuse the advertising of making you buy something, you're just trying to relieve yourself of any actual responsibility for your own actions. Look at your own language 'create new needs', how is something a need if it first has to be created through manipulation?  This whole video from start to finish is about taking personal failings, and inability to control ones own actions and trying to lump the blame on an economic system that can only do these things if people voluntarily support such a system.

Here's four simple goals, a minimal programme of radical social change:   The first two are shorter term goals, like a starting basis, to be won by electoral politics in conjunction with labor struggles and community struggles, protests, direct action like blockades, sit-ins, occupations, and civil disobedience actions:  1. Actually implement basic human rights as proclaimed in the UDHR (both socio-economic ones like housing, healthcare, and jobs for all, strong social safety system; and politico-civil ones, including the stamping out discrimination and bigotry).  2. Have a robust social-democratic economic structure (strong regulations - environmental, health, safety, labor, etc, state interventions and investments, nationalization and municipalization of large-scale and middle-scale economy like infrastructure, healthcare, housing, education, finance, etc).  The latter two are the radical goals to be won at the same time by being a massive movement which forces structural change via super massive protests, a general strike, massive transportation blockades, and maybe massive occupations of public institutions and of large/important workplaces.  3. Restructure the state so that all public administration workers become genuine public servants (by instituting strong mechanism of public participation, a lot of referenda, meaningful participatory oversight over the executive and the judiciary, participatory budgeting, relatively small maximum wages for all public servants). 4. Make all private firms worker coops.  After achiving these four goals, then the fifth goal is to automatize production more and more, and along with doing that, to increasingly nationalize and municipalize firms, and reduce work hours, and keep doing that until we have fully automated communism.

I really like your style, and I like many of your points, and I agree with many of your perceived problems, but I just cannot agree with any of your conclusions. For example, the idea that the point of advertisement is basically brainwashing people into buying things that they don't need is a little bit misleading. The main point of advertisement is to tell people about the existence of their product. Even if you have a very good business, let's say a very good and cheap carpentry business, if you do zero advertisement, even if people do need a carpenter and your business would be the best choice for their needs, if they don't know you even exist, they will not use your services. The main problem I have with your whole argument, is that you are basically just talking about big businesses as if they are not only the root of all the problems of society, but as if capitalism is just those big businesses, when it is not true. You can have your own business, do your own thing; but where I do agree with you is with this idea and lie that you will be rich, because for most people in society this just isn't true, and I can understand why people would be pissed of about it because they were 'lied to', but it isn't some kind of conspiracy, and you can blame the whole of society for it (Well, you can, but it makes no sense). I never get when people talk about how awful capitalism is because of advertising. What do you plan to replace it with? The welfare state? Isn't that just blatant physical coercion? You can't exactly opt out of taxes, and that seems a lot worse than advertising, since you can definitely just turn your television off, or like not buy shit you don't actually want. Whenever I see left wing people talk about capitalism it seems like they blame it for anything that they don't like. It probably helps that the definition of capitalism is often so vague that it can be applied to Switzerland, a wartime economy, the Swedish economic system, or really any system with wage labor. In the beginning of this video you seem to imply that the war on terror is a product of the capitalist system. How? What about the increase in the scope and size of government and the massive collateral damage that always comes with war is consistent with the principle of respect for the individual and their right of self ownership. I'm sure some rich people became richer as a result of that war, but to show that it is the result of capitalism you have to show that it is a natural outgrowth of these principles (unless you have another definition of capitalism to offer). whoa, hold on, forgive this second comment. 'capitalism needs the state to maintain its power' this sentence is flawed and i'll explain why. capitalism is the natural result of free trade. societies that support the idea of hierarchical business, lead to CEO heads being stupid rich. in anarcho-capitalism, there would be no state head to bribe, so companies would have to deal with private arbitrators and private courts.   you could still argue they could buy off those people, which is a fair shot at Ancapistan as not being much better than things are now in some ways. but at the same time, big government has the power to legitimize the actions of a company on mass scale, whereas if you had a bunch of people who had the same guns as the military does, and a company decides to do shitty stuff, like pollute water, whip workers, whatever they do, well then the people can make a conscious effort to negotiate, guns in hand, to tell those CEOs to fuck off.   the problem isn't as much as it is capitalism, but the chaotic results that capitalism provides. if i say 'i want to trade you this, for that' i do not want a government telling me i can't sell to you, or worry about being taxed on trades. it's not so much that i am in full support of capitalism, as i am in full support in trading what i want, to who i want, without a state fucking me in the ass.   as to my point, capitalism doesn't need a state to maintain its power because it doesn't have power, capitalism is not a person, it is the result of people of both having the freedom to trade what and with who they want, and people agreeing to the existence hierarchical big businesses.   what is the solution to this? really depends on a lot honestly. in anarcho-syndicalism, everyone in a company would get paid roughly the same, have the same amount of say as a CEO would, and maybe some pay difference based on meritocracy and/or overly effort put in, but if society supported companies more like this, perhaps that would be more up your alley?

With the exception of the bit about the plight of the homeless people, I don't feel you really address what's problematic about capitalism specifically. You more just describe ennui and subjective impressions of consumerism as bad. A lot of people like consumerism. The marketing can be entertaining; the food can be delicious; collecting physical items that people feel fits their personalities can be psychologically gratifying; the bare walls of the North Korean station can represent human suffering where no one creates wealth and no one has the ability to get things they want, if you choose to look at it that way. I think maybe because you personally are sick of the status quo and surround yourself with people who feel the same way, you've lost sight of what makes it attractive at all and see it as a foregone conclusion that the world around you is awful and that this sentiment can easily be communicated and subsequently propagated when realization is made. Many people can understand but not agree.  This ennui-based disdain of capitalism is dismissable by people who really care about capitalism because it doesn't address the nature of violence at the heart of the matter. The socialist view is that there is a problematic hierarchy inherent to capitalism where those at the top exploit those at the bottom, who are at threat of harm from natural forces such as sickness and hunger, and that the artificiality of the capitalist system renders this a form of violence conducted by the powerful against the impoverished, so the idea of violence to bring about the end of the artificial system is logically ethical. The capitalist view is that the natural forces to which people in poverty are subjected have no people to blame for them, representing a natural neutral state, and that wealth created by business is an entirely separate artificial construct that betters humanity. Without having an understanding of the socialist conception of the violence committed by people who maintain capitalism, your argument seems bizarrely violent, jumping from subjective emotion-based disdain for consumerism to advocating violent revolution or the slightly less direct violent revolution of voting into power people who will command the cops to enact violence against those who will not go along with having their wealth--self-made in the artificial construct of capitalism that betters humanity--stolen to better people who suffer only from natural forces and not anything for which anyone is to blame. You won't convince people truly invested in capitalism without understanding how they think and focusing on the issue they care about: the perception of the installation of socialism as more violent than the maitenance of capitalism. Otherwise, you're just preaching to the choir. If you aren't planning already to address it in a future part, you might want to think about it.

It saddens me that people have such a poor grasp of economics that they turn against capitalism. Capitalism has many problems its by no means a perfect system, it is however the far best functioning system we have ever tried. There are reasons why the richest countries in the world are capitalistic, there are reasons why all succesful capitalistic countries are based around freedom.  Capitalism is what is paying for your schools, for your welfare that is what capitalism is paying for through taxes because capitalism doesnt naturally grow these areas well. If you are against capitalism tell me any other system that is going to work.  Capitalism basically uses our wish to have more to reinvest our own profits to produce even more jobs, you work hard and you get promoted and you start earning more money then you can spend but the system works so that you want to spend that money on something, lets say a capital investment in a new business in return if it works out you make some money and if it doesnt you lose it all. This creates jobs all the time because a company uses their profits the same way, they give some money to their investors and share holders, they pay for the expertise of their personell, they pay for everything and with whats left they can try to expand or give out bonuses.  Are you against bonuses? Well why is anyone, because people dont understand that its a reward to the people that has increased the profits of the company, why would anyone work their ass off for a year on the slim chance that they make it even better if they cant get a reward for it if they are succesful. We need to incentivise taking economic risks for the companies so they want to reinvest their money on the market so more jobs are created.  All companies seek to be more effective naturally so over time they will produce more with less workers, this creates unemployment, so we need another system so they will reinvest their new profits, that is what capitalism does. It creates more jobs, which will reduce unemployment which in turn increases wages naturally because of supply and demand. As the supply of able bodied people lowers and the demand of them goes up wages will follow because they need to incentivise people to work for them.  If you disagree please explain why and i will gladly listen i am just as interested as you are at making the world a better place for everyone. Capitalism has many problems without a doubt we simply have no better system.  Socialism doesnt work, im a Swede and i can tell you how it fails. Regarding shitty jobs. Is it necessary for capitalism? It's more of a 'path of less resistance' in capitalism, which ends up in hierarchical big organizational structures. In IT there are various private 'capitalistic' companies and organizations with better structures where there is less hierarchy, more autonomy, and freedom to allow each employee to have a say in their work (be it what they need to do, how they need to do it, etc). There's also a shift towards making the job less shitty, not ony so the employee actually performs the job better, but so the employee may find ways to make the work even better (not just perform the same routine, but find a more efficient or optimal way, find new technology or proceses that end up improving the company), but also to make it ethical and rewarding (in a humanitarian sense, but also thinking long-term, making that workplace attractive, having good PR, etc). It works, it is still capitalistic but no 'shitty job' or 'alienation of your work'. Granted, so far I'm only seeing it applied in IT, where the context is very specific. The problems being solved, products being created, work being done, etc, is complex and having workers not feel shitty directly improves those products (unlike a factory worker, where the worker feeling shitty or not has much less impact on the final product). There is also a shitload of demand so the companies need incentives to keep high-skilled employees and attract talent. But surely it can be applied in different ways in different industries.

If you want to reap the full benefits of your labour in a capitalist society, you are totally free to self-employ & be your own business. Not all employers are MegaCorp CEO lizard people.  Most people don't pick this route. There's no guarantee you'll find clients & get paid *at all*, you're going to spend a lot of your time doing things other than what you're good at, you probably are going to need to invest some startup funds and are going to take some time before you so much as break even, and for all you know there's a new invention coming out next year that will make what you're selling completely obsolete. So this either requires you start with a decent amount of capital, or have someone who does and is willing to take a chance on you (which gets easier the better your idea is). But if you want to get the full value of your services, this is a risk you have to take on, because nothing obligates people to buy your shitty homeopathic vitamin supplement. (High risk, high reward.)  When you choose to work for someone, you shift all of that burden onto them. Instead, you now get a static, consistent, reliable, and comparatively immediate payout. Sure, you may get fired on short notice, but you're legally entitled to compensation for every hour you have spent on the factory floor. (Low risk, low reward.)  There's a bunch of intermediate possibilities, some good, some bad. Giving employees shares in the company, working for commission/tips, pyramid schemes, performance based raises & promotion, partnerships, independent contracting, hiring an agent to find contracts for you, etc. All of them are different arrangements people have independently come up with to try and find an agreeable arrangement in which all parties involved in the transaction are happy enough with to consent to the exchange.  Regardless of what method you think is best, no one else is bound to your idea of how it should be done. Don't like the price? Shop somewhere else. No one is required to do business with you if your terms are unreasonable to them. They might be wrong about what's reasonable, but so might you. No one is able to be an expert in everything, but the people closest to the most relevant aspects of the industry will know the most (because it's in their self interest to learn) and they will be able to set their own terms. Which encourages most people towards the most reasonable terms for everyone by having selfish interests line up as close as possible with serving the public good.  The socialist/marxist alternative, is to simply violate the consent portion of the exchange. Either forcing someone to provide the service (slavery) or forcing someone to pay for the service (theft). Generally this is something unpalatable to most people, but it manages to catch on as popular by simply targeting an unsympathetic minority (the rich) to fuck over with reckless abandon. Personally I'm not particularly ok with establishing this precedent (even if these people are insufferable), because it establishes that it is *OK* for the majority to just fuck over someone they don't like.

I favor syndicalism. It already exists in various forms (worker owned businesses). It does what socialism claims to do which is put the means of production back in the hands of workers. Whereas socialism ends up putting it in the hands of government bureaucrats with mixed results. Not to be confused with social democracy which means and expanded social safety net and services, which I also favor to some degree.                                    Syndicalism already has a proven track record and the word does not have the baggage that socialism does. It is something that we can all support on a small scale now (by supporting or forming these kinds of businesses), but also on a larger scale in the near future (by lobbying for regulations that favor these kind of businesses), and as a complete shift (once this has become more popular making it the law of the land in place of businesses owned by people who don't work in them). It appeals to both the left and parts of the right. Here is a link with a quick primer URL

there is no perfect system because systems are ran by humans which are inherently flawed. the reason Capitalism is favored by so many, and not just the 1% is because i allows the most freedom of choice for all, but the double edge to this is that monetary economies become very unstable due to decisions made by corporate heads.   i do acknowledge the problems that Capitalism has brung about, but if you are not very careful about how socialism is introduced, it could lead to problems of it's own. every system has it's problems. sure, i don't enjoy knowing some people will always be richer than kings, and it's nothing but struggle and/or luck that can get you up the chain, but what is the alternative? North Korea? communist China?   i'm a radical idealist, hoping for an end of centralized systems, or at least a great downgrading. instead of unifying all under a huge governmental state, why not go down to the community level? at least until we figure out how to make replicators or some way to become post-scarcity.   whichever way we go, government or not, i at least want as much freedom as i possibly can without it being a problem. i want to own whatever gun i want, do whatever drug i want, and within consent, have love with whoever i want. i want to end, or at least greatly reduce taxation, and replace government subsidization and 'safety net' programs with a societal culture of charity and encouraged fundraising.   i am a Voluntaryist. i have no clear endgame, i will support whatever ends up working out, but i aim somewhere between Minarchism, Anarcho-Capitalism, Mutualism, or Anarcho-Syndicalism. i'm also open to the idea of a Resource Based Economy as explained by the Venus Project.

I try and use the best labels I can to guide my best understanding as to how we can make the world a better place. And a lot of that world looks very capitalistic. By that, I mean, there are a lot of ways in which my ideal would still has a lot of the same mechanisms in place. I still think that finance is an important thing, and that under the ideal society, as I can imagine it, the stocks and money that act as abstractions for the goods and services and the means of production of either are simply more spread around. We can probably get rid of certain speculative instruments that do nothing to help drive the creation of wealth. Advertising should be nearly done away with, or, at least, massively reformed in order to emphasize appreciation rather than desire. Unsustainable desire should be well managed rather than encouraged. We should still have money, just that the money should be better distributed, with a possible system of basic needs guarantee which will ensure that a certain amount of shelter and nutrition and clothing, and access to social society is free upon purchase, if such a system is both possible and not superfluous. And all of this is just me laying out what I can actually understand as possible. I would not mind if we go 'further' or if there are better alternatives to these and other ideas, but I cannot advocate for them unless I can personally understand how they would be functionally possible. Some of the ideas I put forward might be practically impossible to realize, but because I can both theoretically realize them happening, and can also realistically immagine them happening with an achievable level of solidarity, I don't see the practical impossibility. But the second step after recognizing there is a problem is to elucidate solutions and why they are feasible, and why the seemingly impossible is actually possible with enough tenacity.

I think one of the big problems is that we shouldn't be aiming for 'capitalism.' We've let dogshit marxists control the intellectual narrative for too long. Capitalism is a pejorative, at least made popular by (if not created by) Karl Marx.  The issue is that real thinkers like Adam Smith didn't actually aim to rhetorically advance their values. Adam Smith laid out a series of arguments about general practices that are pretty good ideas and tended to increase wealth in nations. That's not to say that Smith didn't have a political agenda, but it is to say that he didn't really create polarizing categories in Wealth of Nations. Like, just look at the language that Marx uses: 'a spectre is haunting Europe. . .' There's so much more passionate energy in Marx than there is in Smith.  I think the problem is that even if you're not a Marxist, you still see the world through a marxist lens now.  If we're going to overcome capitalism, we're going to have to overcome marxism.

You need concentration of surplus and incentive for investment  to create a instrument of expansion for a civilization. Capitalism is so far the best system in this regard. Sadly it has become institutionalized and the concentrations of surplus (corporations and megarich people) no longer invest as much(with exceptions found in people like Elon Musk) - but instead spend the money on nonproductive luxuries and extravagances, but most harmfully security, lobbying and general perpetuation of their position of power.  Socialist turn to the state, as it indeed is a concentration of surplus, but do not realize that it is even more institutionalized than the capitalist structure (or rather, the organisations than live in the capitalist structure) - using nearly the entirety of the collected surplus not for investment, but to secure and perpetuate the status quo with huge military, policiary and most of all welfare budgets. When was last time we had the government actually investing in the country? When was the last 'New Deal'? The infrastructure is in disrepair, but still so much money is spent on unproductive enteprises (walls are a sign of decline, they do not create surplus, only protect existing surplus). Truly, capitalism is not as far gone, as we still have concentrations of surplus within the structure that invest in the projects that increase capital rather than tear on it, as can be seen with Elon Musk among others. But the thing many notice now is how many rich and powerfull actually do not try to increase the output of the system, only living off of the output like parasites. What we are aproaching is the status quo. Then comes the decline. Maybe we will get a new instrument of expansion? Maybe capitalism will be reformed.

A significant problem here is that healthcare, public education, and helping the homeless are things that, for the most part, the government is being expected to do-- and they're doing it poorly for a lot of hard economic reasons-- third party payer problem, protectionism, etc.  It's even difficult to feed the homeless without a pile of specially scrutinized licenses and permits.

Blaming capitalism for extreme consumerism (and its malaise) is sort of like blaming modern farming techniques for obesity.  I mean, it's true in the sense that they allow consumerism and obesity-- but those are consequences of its success in satisfying people's desires.  What needs the social pushback are consumerism and obesity themselves, because help is readily available there too and the current alternatives to free markets and modern farming have much worse consequences for human well-being.  Is it really so difficult to see through marketing?  That's something that even young children learn to do with some ease.  Who are you going to prevent from offering people delicious tacos in exchange for goods and services, ContraPoints?  If you don't have any stake in the profits of your employer, then your employer wouldn't have hired you.  There is no charity here-- you work for them because you value the money they pay more than that time and labor; they pay you a certain amount because they value your time and labor more than the amount they pay.  Both sides try to get the best they can, and if the discrepancy is too large because of the power difference, you have a right to organize and pursue collective bargaining during negotiation-- or acquire more skills that allow you to be more individually competitive.  Marx was wrong about labor having objective value, its value is subjective just like anything else-- this is the contemporary economic view, and has been for a long time.   It's difficult to experience companionship with other people in your situation?  Sorry, but that's complete horseshit.  Have you ever held an actual job?  Or watched workers socialize at a job? I think criticism of capitalism is warranted, but my question is - what would you replace it with? Capitalism has facilitated some of the greatest innovations in western civilization and pushed us into the dynamic, technologically advanced society that we live in. What other economic system could do the same? It is true that money is the root of all evil whilst simultaneously making the world go round.

It's a bit disingenuous to imply that radicals have no plans, and that if there isn't a clear cut plan then you should dismiss any kind of direct action by radicals in favour of parliamentary reform. Radicals talk often about expropriation of private property, or getting communities to organise themselves in a less capitalist manner (one completely free of capitalism would be nigh impossible without a revolution alongside it since, you know, basically the whole world is capitalist), to give some examples of action more specific than 'smash' or 'revolution'.   Also, changing things through the state is wholly ineffective since the state is controlled by political parties, which are themselves controlled almost entirely by people in the capitalist class. Even Bernie Sanders, popular as he was, would never have had any chance at all if he actually actively argued against capitalism in any meaningful way since he's really a social democrat at heart. He never said that value forms or wage labour should be abolished, or that private property should be expropriated and put to communal use or anything like that and if he had, he would have been out of the race way sooner than he was because the democratic party would have sabotaged the shit out of him.

Obviously this is part one of a series but isn't there something to be said about the trade-offs of capitalism and other systems? Ultimately, alienation and other classical Marxist criticisms of capitalism are accurate but compared to other economic systems, we seem to have been able to eliminate absolute poverty at an outstanding rate, many of the issues which used to plague people in the 20th century are virtually gone now, and it all around seems like there are substantially positive welfare effects to permitting markets to efficiently operate even if it may lack any real compassion or concern. The amount of production and wealth that is created in capitalism has the side benefit of permitting societies to invest in services that otherwise they could not afford. Contrast to other systems around the world, I think it's a big difference.

I can't exactly blame you for misunderstanding the Marxist critique of reformism when most 'Marxists' don't actually understand it. But the element that is missing is that fundamentally, you are still viewing the world through an idealist lens. And I don't mean idealism as in the colloquial sense of being idealistic, but rather of the philosophical position that social reality is ultimately immaterial, and determined by ideas.  Your response to the ongoing social problems of capitalist society and the economic contradictions inherent in political economy is fundamentally one of changing people's minds. From the reformist position which you seem uncomfortable with but seem to always fall back on, it is fundamentally a matter of 'corrupt' systems, of bad people in office, and these matters can be changed by convincing people to get out the vote, and implement redistributive policies, a 'peaceful' alternative to violent revolution.  But ultimately, it's not non-violent. The state is institutionalized violence, and the program of social democracy relies upon the coercive powers of the state to function. But beyond that, the idealist position is flawed for a number of reasons. Capitalism isn't shitty because a bunch of 'reptiles' are in charge. It is fundamentally a misanthropic system, and the economic demands for capital to accumulate and circulate are beyond the control of any individual.  Classic social democracy didn't die because a cabal willed neoliberalism into being. The rate of profit inexorably fell, and the economies across the western world were in deep systemic crisis throughout the 70s. The end result destroyed the protectionist state mediated capitalism that made such welfarism possible. And in many cases, it was precisely social democratic parties that implemented this transition.

I don't think movements to increase wages and provide acceptable healthcare are useful for anything but building popular support. Reform is a bandage over an infected wound, it does little but disguise the fact that your condition is fatal. Revolution is the alcohol that cleanses that wound, and though it may sting for a moment you will survive. Doubtlessly, it is better to have the bandage than nothing at all, but it's not the cure we should strive for.  Regardless of how these reforms will benefit us, it should not be forgotten that the capitalist will use other methods to maintain his profits (dented as they would be by social reforms). In our modern age, this is generally achieved by moving jobs overseas (generally to less industrialized countries without such regulations). This encourages exploitation of third-world countries by larger, more industrialized countries. While we may achieve our goals of increasing the minimum wage, it could have the effect of opening more sweatshops in developing nations. Such economic imperialism should be taken into account before we take to the streets to lightly improve our own situation.  So, while certain reforms should be sought after, this is not the end goal. There is no point in reforming capitalism that it becomes socialism. Reform will never resolve the exploitation and alienation of the working class. Every move should be in preparation for revolution.  That being said, I think you're attracting a lot of people to leftism. This was a video of astounding quality and craftsmanship. Thank you for what you do.  Here is a favorite address of mine by American socialist Daniel Deleon on the topic of reform or revolution. URL

While I agree with ContraPoints on most issues, she (is this your preferred pronoun?) is frankly wrong in this video.  The fundamental problem with critiques of capitalism is not that the critiques are wrong per se - it's the failure to put those problems in the context of history.  Compared to the issues that humans have had throughout history, the problems of 'alienation' and cultural problems that we have today are nothing compared to being unable to get basic needs, having huge rates of child mortality, and lackl of education to name a few.   Previously third world countries in Asia that have embraced capitalism such as Singapore, South Korea, Japan, and (more recently) China have experienced incredible increases in standard of living.  Such increases have never been seen in other non-capitalist systems - the average economic growth of the Soviet Union, being the most major non-capitalist society in the modern era, was significantly lower than of the United States during the period.  Furthermore, ContraPoints makes some straw mans of capitalist thoughts.  For instance, she states that a cornerstone of capitalist thought is that we are autonomous and rational beings.  However, the most recent nobel prize went to a behavioral economist, a field that explores the ways in which we are not rational and is rapidly growing.  Despite these changes, the field of economics still has not, and likely never will, embrace  planned economies (the only alternative to market systems).  This is they do not stand up to virtually any deep empirical or theoretical criticisms.  Another factual mistake that ContraPoints makes is the assertion that in the United States, basic needs are not generally met.  While there are serious issues in this country, literal starvation is exceptionally rare, especially when put in historical contexts.  The two main issues she cites are medical debt and student debt.  However, firstly, both of these issues are ones that only occur in the context of societies that are already thriving in which people expect to have health insurance and be educated, expectations that have not been the case throughout human history.  Furthermore, these issues can all be addressed in a capitalist framework.  Plenty of capitalist countries have universal health care and more subsidization for education than the U. S.  Using the U. S. as a posterboy for capitalism is disingenuous.  I actually agree with ContraPoints' fundamental preface - that economic systems should increase well-being.  But capitalism is doing that.

I think a lot of this is a little dishonest relative to your usual stuff. I only really wanna look at one example because I think you will know what I mean given one example. I also think that it is irrelevant to the specific points you make about class angst and social justice. I only point out that your reasoning is very imprecise and coddles people focused on petty resentment.   Take the Comcast employee/CEO comparison.  You say:   - CEO makes 32 million/year - you make 14 dollars an hour --> this means that a lot of value you produce goes right up the chain of command  This is purposely dishonest I have to imagine.   Compare annual. 28k vs 32000k. Number of employees: ~150k. Let's say that 145000 of these are average 28k, 5000 are average of (generously) 128k. One at 32000k. 532000k would be the surplus if everyone were reduced to 28k. That divided by 150k is about 3.5k. So, assuming you don't care about seniority, specialization of skill, premiums on responsibility, etc, the huge amount you would be losing to upper management is something like 12-13%. If you only look at the CEO, that would be ~200/employee, less than a percent of annual salary.

Hi, ContraPoints. Your videos are fun and thoughtful. Thanks. A few quick points. The Soviet Union and Maoist China are complete non-starters. Let's not even go there. Unless we're not sure that they were complete disasters - which of course they were. I would only bother to discuss these dinosaurs with residual Trots and Maoists (and I don't think I've ever met a Maoist). Otherwise, for most people, it's a distraction to even raise them. And to make of them some kind of point or argument in the mouth of a hypothetical radical smacks almost of straw man. Now, about revolution. I agree that a direct confrontation with the capitalist system is impractical, to say the least. We are unarmed, obviously, and can't count on defections on the part of the armed forces; there are no Kronstadt sailors in the modern world. So our task is to come up with other, more imaginative, creative ways of disrupting and undermining the system. Part of that has to  be free public education, which is why work such as yours is important and valuable. But there have to be other things too. We need to think carefully about how the capitalist system works and what its weaknesses are and then attack it at those points. It is a complex system - the financial sub-system, for example  - which means there have to be many weaknesses in the technical infrastructure. I don't have the answers; it's something I think about. But next time you do a discussion on What To Do, such as the one in this video, I would love to see some brainstorming about real concrete measures, instead of some fairly obvious points (no offence) about how it's not 1917 anymore (though this is true, and unfortunately it's a point that might actually need to be made) and about Marxist jargon, etc. (I realise this is only Part 1.) Of course, that isn't easy. But we might start by trying to at least identify which parts of capitalism are more vulnerable and open to attack - and greater focus may open up possible strategies. Finally, none of this means of course that we cannot also do whatever we can in terms of more conventional, reformist politics and industrial action, etc.

Happiness is to be achieved not bought.  The rich man: How can you achieve happiness when you have nothing?  The poor man: How can you achieve happiness when you have everything? Dear ContraPoints,  Fantastic video, as always! I love all of your thoughts as well as your video-making style. You do a terrific job at broadcasting leftist ideas to a broad audience. I mean, sixty-nine THOUSAND subscribers?? It's amazing to see how much you have grown!  I really love that you want to delve deeply into the 'reform' versus 'revolution' debate. Of course, you are right it is best to use all the tactics we have at our disposal (within reason) to move closer to the society that we want.  I'm no authority on any of this stuff, (obviously) but this is what I think: When it comes to reforms, we should aim to pass those that truly undermine capitalism rather than try to save it, such as a universal employment guarantee and the socialization of industry. As for insurrection, we should never use preemptive violence, as that contorts our struggle into something that it is not. We need to show people that we are fighting for their liberation from their oppressors, not needlessly inflicting pain against our enemies. We should organize to defend ourselves when we have to and capitalize on all of the ways we have of resisting peacefully.  Anyways, those are just my two cents. I'd be flattered if you even read this, gosh you're so cool. By the way, thank you for introducing me to Bela Fleck's Bach, I really enjoyed that. Have a restful day, and stay awesome! As a 'Dirty Centrist', progressive/socialist policy really tugs at my heart-strings, but there are some fundamental questions that it seems progressives just can't answer:  1) What are the appropriate levels of taxation for different incomes? (Thomas Piketty says 80% on income $1M+) 2) How much estimated Gov't revenue would be generated at those levels? (I can't find any data on this, but I can find articles that attack these tax rate directly: URL 3) For whatever Gov't revenue is generated, how would it be directed to social programs (I personally estimate that Healthcare, Education, Infrastructure & Poverty are all trillion dollar+ endeavors, so $4T to devote to each as a START)  I get that capitalism comes with a multitude of social, environmental and inter-personal issues, but unless progressives can provide some concrete answers to the above questions, ultimately people are going to choose Centrist Dems over Far Left Progressives, because we can't shake the nagging feeling that a lot of these economic policies are feel-good fantasy.

This is a great indictment of a certain type of capitalism, but nobody who isn't a Republican or Libertarian doesn't see the problem with this sort of capitalism. I have never seen evidence that a system that rejects free markets entirely can succeed. The fact is you need incentives to do the enormous amount of work required to move the massive amounts of resources to their approximately efficient end goal. Not only the incentive of profit (which is why compensation for labor must always be less than the value it creates, as unfair as this seems; the Christians of the middle ages thought it was unfair too, which is why society stayed stagnant and miserably poor until this thinking changed), but the incentive of fear of loss. If you're not worried that an investment may be rejected by the market, you're mindlessly investing in resources that the market may reject. This was a huge problem is soviet Russia.  Whenever a liberal like myself writes something like this, I'm always met with accusations that I'm out of touch, insensitive to the needs of the poor, etc. On the contrary. Living standards have never been higher than in the age of liberal capitalism. There's nothing that even comes close to comparison. And while I agree that we need to do a LOT more - there is a lot of economic injustice - you don't need to dismantle capitalism to do it. Just practice a different form of it. Of course in doing so you might get purist libertarians who say this isn't capitalism at all, but it still is.   The problem with revolutions, either with ballots or bullets, is that unless you strip away democracy you need to convince a comfortable majority in society that it's a good idea to rule this way. Otherwise you might get a Trotskyan one election cycle and a Donald Trump the next. Good luck doing it in the USA, where opinion is split 50/50 on pretty much everything. I personally think American society is fucked for this exact reason, and the only thing that's ever going to form the kind of sane consensus that leads to actual progress is an ENORMOUS disaster that strips away ideology and forces us to look straight into the gaping black hole in our society.

It's been pointed out before that, at least as far as the USSR goes, capitalism was essentially maintained, albeit with an increased amount of direct state intervention. The means of production, after all, were still held firmly by a non-democratic and politically unaccountable minority. Lenin's vanguard party, alas, had all the fun.   The question remains, however. If the USSR is a poor example to follow, what is the alternative?   Also of note: both the Russian and Chinese empires were agrarian monarchies with very little that a devoted Marxist would consider prerequisite for a revolution that got beyond capitalism. In other words, they're very far from examples that meet our current situation. They may serve as useful historical analogies or cautionary tales or what have you, but play-by-play guides for how we ought to proceed they very much are not.

I really do enjoy all the characters in your videos but I don't know if they're an effective way to present the arguments... they veer too close to caricatures and strawpeople a bit too often. At least in my view. And it ends up coming off as Moderate Leftist Lecturing Radical Leftists Who Are Too Childish To Realise The Error Of Their Ways.   I mean I've been following similar debates a lot lately but they were entirely between revolutionary anarchists, because we're not actually cartoon characters. We do talk about these things and look at situations case by case and try to be pragmatic and realistic. We just had a whole discussion about potentially pushing for UBI because we are very aware of the fact that immediate concerns exist and matter and it's worth considering the costs and benefits. Many of us desperately need the immediate relief ourselves. We also do work with moderates and other leftists, quite a lot even. It's often practical, even if there is some debate over the matter.  I mean maybe Tabby is just a young online activist with no connections to real life groups and no experience (which is what she sounds like to me) but I feel like then the solution is to get her some comrades to talk things over with.  As for the revolution thing btw, I don't think anyone realistically has such a naive idea of how revolutions happen. Nobody thinks you can just hand out some pamflets and start an insurrection whenever you want. Okay maybe a handful of people, idk. But typically what happens is that there is some sort of a build up to it which changes the balance of power and the public opinion. Some sort of tension or chaos or even a split in the ruling class. You assume that it'll be civilians against cops and the army but it's not at all unheard of that the cops or even the army (or a part of them) might side with the insurgents if the people in power fuck up enough. Or you can have a situation where the people in power genuinely don't dare to use their violence machine.   It can't really be manufactured so you can only wait for the right moment and hope for the best. I can't predict the future, I don't know if this'll happen in our lifetime in our countries, but it's not as absurd as you seem to think. Basically I recommend reading about revolutionary history. I promise it's not boring.

In my opinion, the difference between democratic (I prefer 'reform') and revolutionary socialism is minute and almost trivial.  The ruling class will not surrender their powers without a fight, the French feudal aristocracy refused to concede basic rights to the peasants. Today, it is the capitalist class which wields the state. Though they have not and will not capitulate without a fight, that does not mean we must avoid engaging the ruling class and demand reform. Democratic and revolutionary socialism are two sides of the same coin, socialism is inherently both democratic and revolutionary. Love your work, but I wasn't a fan of this one. I think you're criticism of capitalism could have been better. Materialism has existed with and without capitalism, why else do tribal chiefs decorate their selves with jewels and headdresses and such? It's about status and that is a part of humans when they coexist in a community.  You give too much credit to advertisements and not enough to people. I think you're making the mistake of looking at people as a collective, rather than as individuals, which I understand is hard to do. But most people I know avoid ads like the plague and the best way to sell a product is by word of mouth. I do agree with you on some aspects of your criticism of ads, but I think this topic requires a more objective analysis. As I said, ads are representative to status, which exists independently of capitalism (but I admit, gets a boost under it). You may be getting too Utopian. Unfortunately, the reality is that we DON'T live in a pure capitalist society. We live in a mixed system, so there's no simple answer.  What you're proposing would require a top down centralized approach. So instead of ads coming at us from every which direction and going to dead end jobs, the gov't would TELL us what we want and what we will do. I'm just not a fan of this either.  You're absolutely right about the shit jobs and debt and inequality. Bravo.
