A spectre is haunting not just Europe, but the world. What is this spectre? Is it communism? Something is happening. I don't know what, but something is.  It is high time the radical left crawls out of their sectarian and dogmatic echo-chambers and start talking to each other and the rest of the left again. And I mean talking, and not throwing accusations of opportunism back and forth. For so long a siege mentality has held sway within the radical left, all the while fetishizing revolutions from the 20th century.  Should we read Marx? yes, but we should also read Bakunin and Kropotkin. Should we read Lenin? Yes, but we should also read Pannekoek and Luxemburg. And above all, we maybe should spend a little less time reading and a little more time looking at the current state of the world, and draw our own, 21st century conclusions.  Will we be able to make the capitalists bow to our will? Will reformism inevitably result in a kind of mild Keynesian capitalism, but still keep the masses bound in wage-slavery? Will revolutionary fervour always result in the horrors of Stalinist authoritarianism? I honestly do not know the answers to these questions. But the left has to definitely re-invent itself if we want to make the dream of universal human liberation a reality.

Fantastic music!  But... most ACAB- button wearing cat people I know would answer you something like this, to What do we do now?   1. ORGANIZE a new society in the shell of the old. Amidst capitalism's (death rattle?) spasms, we build new liberatory institutions that create a new safety net, an onramp to a new counter culture social order, make an alternative life better and, and eventually (??) enable people to opt out of the old society -- the shitty jobs, credit reports and welfare system -- and just sustain themselves off the new great shit we made.   2. ORGANIZE strategic and/or spiritual direct confrontations with the state and corporations now and now and now. Simultaneously while we build our new world in the shell of the old, we challenge the hulking systems that cause suffering and egregious injustices all around us and everywhere through exploitation and oppression. Without major successes in this step, all our efforts toward a new world will be nipped in the bud, so.

The answer is actually surprisingly simple yet difficult and time consuming. Slowly work on replacing all important corporations with democratically run co-operatives so to fundamentally undermine the source of corporate power, ie. the money consumers pay for the products and put that power in the source of democratically run entities. Trying to permanently limit capitalist corporate power through law and government will never be anything more than a speed-bump for them. How do you do this in an individual level? 1. See if you can buy the products that you are already buying regularly from a co-operative that already exists. If this is too hard, at least try to by locally sourced and from companies that you know don't pay their workers slave wages even if what you want to buy is more expensive and you have to wait longer to buy it. You'll fail to resist, but keep trying. This is like dieting level hard. 2. Apply for a job at a co-operative yourself and help them with your personal productivity. Note that this is not about charity. This is about a paid job. 3. Usual stuff about finding like minded people in the meat-world (actually fucking meeting people in person who agree with you about capitalism being terrible etc.) and organize and start your own co-operative and compete with some capitalist corporation to, as they like to say, 'make it redundant'. Often this will devolve into shouting because there's nothing worse to our leftist cause then us getting together and all knowing how fucking right we are and only if those assholes would just shut up for a moment to listen to you. Again, persist and be patient. Also, in times like this many of the suggestions will be about getting into politics. Remember, we have already tried this. Politics can help but they will never be a complete solution. The need that the corporations create (artificial or not) needs to be met by democratic entities to finally undermine the capitalists real power. Money from us, the filthy masses. 4. Some politics are necessary to play interference when the capitalist try to end the right of co-operatives to exists via their favourite means, political mind control (ie. bribery and threats).  The best thing about this method is that it's gradual and non-violent. Just replace the lego-bricks one by one. Maybe you think that this is pipe-dream? You might be surprised to know that there are thousands and thousands of co-operatives all around the world already. Even your local bakery might be one! Just search online, there's already lots of em. Do note that just because some company is a co-operative doesn't mean that it's perfect or practices perfect ethics in business or how it treats its workers, but it's much harder to fuck workers over when they have a vote on how the products are produces, when, where, how and how the profits are spent.  This is the only non violent way that I know of that might someday end capitalism. I'm not holding my breath or anything, but it would be nice. Thanks for the video. Cheers.

i do think one should be careful to see marxism as a reaction against the evils of the bourgeoise, considering they are also slaves under the logic of a market which is far above any of our control. a large part of communism is about mankind taking control over the forces of production, rather than the forces of production reproducing themselves endlessly through us.  that said, of course the bourgeoise is the prime defender of the status quo and the revolution will of course be against them, but not against them because they are 'evil'. getting stuck in only defeating the representations, rather than the origin of representation itself, will always lead to capital being able to restructure itself around, and assimilate resistance.  i do believe a capitalism which is no better than the current one, while not having a defined bourgeoise represented in a specific class, is possible, and might be what we are heading towards, if not this whole neoreaction and CEO-god-emperor thing is the next thing.

I've thought about this one. I honestly think that Capitalism can be subverted. There's no reason why you couldn't apply Marxist theory to a small corporate entity. In fact, from a business perspective, there are a lot of compelling reasons to do it. Time to market, turnaround, faster response to real-world conditions, and so on. Enough smaller high productivity groups will eventually strangle out the big slow moving corporate dinosaurs, and there isn't a damned thing you can do about it, without hurting the very creature of capitalism.  It can be done without radical change to the system, even though the idea would constitute a radical change to the system itself. My plan revolves around financing. Change the moral considerations around investment, what it is, who benefits, for how long... and the whole system tilts.

A lot of people who consider themselves capitalists would agree that the problems identified in each chapter are 'problems', they just wouldn't assign the blame for those things directly to capitalism. They call such problems things like 'corporatism' (an actual branch of fascism advocated by the likes of Mussolini), and 'consumerism' (which rejects the more rational, materialist descriptions of economics favoured by Thoreau, who placed the value of free time well above the value of practically everything else). The perils of false advertising and rhetorical suggestion are by no means restricted to capitalism - Natalie herself has been quite open about pushing the use of rhetoric to persuade irrational viewers rather than focusing on their need to be better educated. Under other economic systems it's likely a similar broadscale rhetoric would be employed to convince people they 'don't' need products. A deceleration of needs can be just as dangerous as the acceleration, if it means stripping people of the personal products they actually 'do' need to make living worthwhile, and should those products are regarded as unnecessary by those in power.  Though that said, it is also easy for someone who labels themself a 'capitalist' to groan when they hear a critique of capitalism on these terms. It's a bit like what Natalie is saying when she refuses to identify with a political ideology; what actually matters is a nominalist interpretation, the physical body of problems and perceivable actions one can take rather than an abstract umbrella of overlapping classifications used to impose order on seeming chaos. There are problematic actions and behaviors which can be restricted by laws and regulations, but others which are perfectly fine, while still being part of a 'capitalist' system - rewarding innovation, for example, or philanthropy. While the U.S calls itself 'Capitalist', it's actually a democracy run by vying elements of the free market, government, and socialist unions. The 'umbrella' idea of Capitalism is a fiction, and THAT's what's wrong with it. It's impossible to fix or destroy or interact with a universal abstract. I think most capitalists reject the umbrella idea of capitalism in favour of specific policies that attract them, just like communists resent being lumped under a singular idea of 'Red Terror'.  Though the most interesting thing about this video is its intended audience, and what it is persuading them to do. Natalie flattered the Alt-Right by reflecting a great deal of their symbols and signs, trolling fascism in its native language to great effect. It would be wrong to assume that this video isn't doing exactly the same thing to the radical communist left. It certainly isn't aimed at any capitalists miraculously unaware of the institutional evils of the western world, ready to have their eyes opened. It spends its first course confirming the intended audience's beliefs, flattering them by reflecting their worldview (specifically the idea of 'vulgar communism', the conspiracy of rich corporate 'lizard-people' running the world behind closed doors), and then graciously points out the flaws in their methods before suggesting a shift away from radicalism to co-operative democracy. There's something great about that. Because it's attacking the 'umbrella' idea of capitalism not by engaging or changing capitalists, who she presumably doesn't have much of an audience with, but by changing communists, who she does. That's the kind of combative strategy that may actually make the internet a more effective realm of discourse.   I mean, I still think it's a bit duplicitous, which is why this handy note is here for anyone who'd prefer to be aware of the rhetorical tools at work. But I do admire her style.

Before you can bring change, I think you'd have to first start showing an alternative way of living. A small step towards this could be purchasing some cheap land somewhere and putting a community of container homes(or other alternative buildings) on it. You'd still need to run some business to import the necessary materials for living, etc but the ability to cut down your living cost dramatically while having on-site jobs that don't require you to work 9-5 like dogs would be a yuge step (imo) towards showing people alternatives. This could be a temp setup where you bring interested people in for 6 months at a time to try out. This should be enough time to de-program the avg person from thinking they require the typical life. Show them that you can raise your kids full time while getting work done. Getting control of your time is paramount to seeing how our culture misuses it, IMO.

I totally understand the backlash against long-winded jargon-heavy 20th century political theory. It clearly isn't going to light a fire in anyone's loins. But it seems a little disingenuous to simultaneously reject the empty sloganeering of the 21st century radical left ('smash capitalism' 'liberals get the bullet too' etc.) and to reject the reams of writing by the Frankfurt school and anarchist writers - like Bakunin, Bookchin, Kropotkin etc. - that explain those leftist positions. For instance, it isn't really accurate to suggest that the left has no plan for post-revolution (Admittedly, that plan needs some serious updating) Maybe we just need to find a more effective middle-ground, something between populist chanting and Walter Benjamin perhaps? I don't really know. Regardless, it was a great video as always. Keep on contributing to the discussion Contrapoints.

I think you're misunderstanding the meaning of commodity fetishism. It's not about fetishizing consumer items; it's a matter of perceiving human relationships as a matter of economic forces. The *objects* of capitalism stand in for the *subjective* relations that exist in the system. So when we talk about the 'economy growing' or 'keeping inflation in check' it sounds like we're referring to abstractions, but underneath it all there are actual changes in political and social power. What Marx does is foreground these dynamics. Rather than dealing with demand curves and price points, he emphasizes that capitalism is always *political* in character, based on a set of human dynamics that are structured through the process of production.

This was excellent!  I don't think capitalism can be 'overthrown' or 'ended'. Too many people have lived in capitalism, for too long, for there to be any kind of smooth transition to anything else. What we need is exactly as you said: Small, measurable goals, and improvements to capitalism as it stands. Then, the larger goal of changing to something else can be achieved, after all the small goals are met.  I say that because I've probablly been brainwashed by the capitalists to desire things, but I like stuff too on its own, regardless of advertising. I love video games, movies, anime, and more. I'm a PC gamer, so I love powerful gaming PCs you can customize with fun parts. I love stupid little collectible things, merchandise, or brands. But, here's the thing: None of these things are BECAUSE of capitalism. The workers made these things, and in a more fair, ethical system, people would WANT to make these things... rather than NEED to make them because they need money to even survive. The problem is with CEOs, shareholders, and more. Unjustified hierarchies. These are the lizards/reptiles you speak of.  Right now, a lot of things that make capitalism fun, such as branding, should exist for the sake of convenience. And advertisement should exist to just tell you that a product exists, rather than tell you that you NEED it. A lot of things that make capitalism good should be taken out of capitalism, such as the ability to create tons of wealth and cool fun things, then inserted into a better system. Because, right now, there's no way that we can comfortablly transfer over to 'socialism' in the traditional sense. Life is hard... but that doesn't mean we should abandon the fun things we enjoy to go 'smash capitalism'. Like, I don't want to stop drawing for people, buying video games, or having a nice computer, to join a violent uprising. That is not feasible. I know it's selfish, but all I can do right now is donate to 'Our Revolution' or Bernie's 'Sanders Institute' to help. I'll do everything I can, such as sign petitions... even if that might not help much. I just want to live a comfortable, happy life.  So, let's focus on small goals, that everyone can agree with, first. Then more can be achieved!

The problem with Parliamentarianism, getting change done through the system (examples: Bernie Sanders and the Fight for 15), is that it submits to the Capitalists and validates the Bourgeois Democracy we live in. It reinforces the system, as the idea of reforming it has less effort and blood shed than revolution. Rosa Luxemburg and Vladimir Lenin do over this in 'Reform or Revolution' and 'The State and Revolution' respectively if you would like a longer explanation. But for the first world obviously the answer isn't revolution, now at least. The labor aristocracy, the workers who are fattened up on Imperialism and benefits stolen from the third world, do not have 'nothing to lose but their chains'. They also are reactionary in general, most do not even know what socialism is. Practically none have read a single work by Marx, Lenin, Engels, or god forbid Stalin. The course of action is for ML groups to work with anarchists and other leftist groups, sometimes even liberals like the DSA and CPUSA to provide direct aid to the poor and homeless. The Black Panthers did this well. Building class consciousness comes before revolution, and there isn't class consciousness in the USA. And for all leftists, we should be reading our theory. Read Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin, Mao, Hoxha for starters. We should understand Marxist economics and what S/C+V and M-C-M mean. We should also read the works of others, because an echo chamber is not helpful. Reading Kropotkin, Bakunin, Trotsky (yucky), Proudhon, Bookchin, Fukuyama, Smith, Keynes, Mises and so on are helpful. We should be out and spreading the message. We should not fall back on liberal tendencies to refrain from action or attempt Parliamentarianism, as these only subjugate us further to Bourgeois interests. Also, Stalin did nothing wrong but we shouldn't say it to liberals.

With regard to the questions you raised in the video, I think we need both a minimal program and a maximal program.  MINIMAL PROGRAM  * Unconditional basic income to replace the welfare state * Free healthcare, public transport, and university * The creation of a hell of a lot more cooperatives  * Municipalisation (not nationalisation!) of public utilities * Introduction of worker self-management in public enterprises * Introduction of participatory budgeting programs in neighbourhoods * Devolution of local government power to popular assemblies in communities  * Elimination of all laws prohibiting consensual drug use and sexwork * Phased abolition of intellectual property laws (free the digital Oasis) * Gradual abolition of all border controls and restrictions on the free movement of people * Transition to community-owned green energy utilities and internet   MAXIMAL PROGRAM * Replacement of the state with voluntary confederations of free communes * Replacement of private and state enterprises with self-managed cooperatives  * Fostering a socio-cultural environment which emphasises individual autonomy, consent, unity-in-diversity, and the free egalitarian distribution of power.  I'd echo Kropotkin in saying 'peaceful if possible, violent if necessary', and also add 'through direct action if possible, through state action if necessary'.  Using violent and state means may be necessary at some points along the way, but in both cases should only be pursued when the alternatives (pacific and direct-actionist means) fail.

Well, this is gonna be fun. let's write an angry long-winded comment no one will read. Maybe I should finally buy a mic and turn this into an angry long-winded video no one will listen too. Chapter one As a market socialist who was pro-gamergate I really can't agr HEY, DON'T RUN AWAY!  Anyway, since I'm now under the read more button I don't have to care about length. I do have a few points though.  Part 1 I think it's actually more working and lower-middle class young men. Often also the socially awkward. It's not that we were promised the world and didn't get it. It's that we're having it just as shit as anyone else. That we've been abandoned by the system as well. That effort gets unrewarded and that we feel we don't get a fair chance either.   That fair chance is what it is about. Again, we are not the Jocks, we are not the pretty boys. We are the outcasts. We have not been given much beyond some common decency. We are not privileged.   I oppose the term queer as a useless catch-all. I also oppose the occupation of weirdness by people who act like they represent these people because I'm probably more insane than they are.  That said special snowflakes is not an insult for people who are nonstraight or noncis. Rather it is for people who expect us to give anything beyond common decency. It is connected to the fact that sadly the largest voices are often wealthy and well-connected. For them to demand things feels simply preposterous as they have more than we do.   Of course that doesn't mean I'm going to act like there aren't other minorities that are worse of. There are a lot of problems that need solutions. However, I can't address them because I'm always the scapegoat. We are often put into the box of evil people. Hell, we're put there even more often than the actual upper-class perpetrators. According the the orthodoxy people should've sucked it up. But no, they didn't and EA got severe issues from it. Funnily enough gaming is rather anti-corporatist. To add to the discussion around revolution vs democratic socialism - those advocating revolution and claiming that democratic means have never worked, fail to realise that revolution itself has also never really worked, hence why Russia is now capitalist and China state capitalist with a communist iPhone case.   The reason WHY revolutionary socialism hasn't worked and imo won't work, is because it scares other countries into becoming defensive because the revolution itself is violent AF.   Democratic Socialism, on the other hand - hasn't 'never worked', it's just not finished. It's a process. America is probably a poor example but in my country, the UK, democratic socialist governments (notably Atlee's) have provided us with institutions like the NHS, strong labour laws and nationalsied industry. We've had a lot of pushback when the postwar consesus ended and the neoliberal consensus began, however with neoliberalism collapsing right now, it's clear the next stage of socialism is about to begin (at least in Britain).

I don't think it is a difficult problem. Capitalism has to be made to enforce their supposed values. If you put some effort, checks and balances into the system, and if you optimize it to maintain physical and spiritual well being on a good level for all people... it works.   This is what you want from any system, socialist or capitalist. Whatever goal you prioritize before human well being, be it profits, war, maintaining control, etc., people will suffer in ANY system. Just like people suffer in socialist systems that prioritize those things in front of their people.   The solution is in changing the focus, not necessarily the way to get there. The problem is not the idea of free market and globalization. The problem is people caring more about something than the good of society.   The US is a nation of... let's call it 'aggressive foreign politics'. It is pretty clear that the nation prioritizes warfare over welfare. A socialist movement would likely keep it that way, and then you have a socialist military power that doesn't care about it's people.   <3 u

The scariest problem with capitalism is that it constructs the social environment unconsciously and because of that it influences our worldview unconsciously. So it's a primitive system being used by an unknowingly primitive species.  Our brains basically absorb the narratives that appeal to our cognitive biases and transform them into our own presuppositions of the world. Since our brains stopped evolving thousands of years ago, an appealing worldview tends not be a coherent worldview.  Capitalism and democracy main premise is that it rewards the narratives and commodities that appeal to the biases of the populations with money/votes. The more money and votes an individual has the more power to construct the social environment. (A cleaner, a secretary, a house that I use during the holidays, a hobbie, etc...).  So we're all collectively stuck in a cycle. That's why history seems to repeat itself.   If a movement arises that exposed and made accessible those dynamics (how we react to authority, how we infuse shapes with an essence, how we tend to only have the past as a reference, plus all the 175 cognitive biases), we could have a chance at turning capitalism obsolete by putting the responsibility to construct the social environment onto the people. (no authority bias = no armies, no essentialist bias = no religion, no countries, and so on...).  imo this is the only way possible to ensure that a coherent revolution won't be appropriated by a more appealing narrative, it also allows for our worldviews to align by destroying total ideological certainty.

How about democratic technocratic socialism? Capitalism still it exists in some capacity but only for the things that you shat on saying they don't matter. All the base ingredients are still priced however if production is efficient the price lowers to the point of basically being free or actually being free. No more fixed prices. Countries separated into self sufficient zones where all needs are met using the most efficient work plans and systems. Politicians are mandated to have a degree in a stem subject and the higher the degree the more spending budget they get for their campaign trails. Work will be done so the maximum amount of efficiency is met. Profit isn't prioritised, efficiency is. Thinks like healthcare, social care, utilities and education are all free. This system effectively makes capitalism a tool for humanity rather than its own thing with its own whims. This system if done properly will be quite a good thing for the modern world. Although the thing about this system is. It needs common support and it can only be reformed into from another type of viable government. There is no revolution then smash into technocracy. Its inefficient and something against the core ideals of technocracy.
